PETITION.TITLE: Violent Television Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:
We are concerned about the increase in violent television programmes for children and particularly those programmes promoting violent toys that are available for sale in Australia.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray; that you support the Broadcasting (Prohibition of Violent Programmes for Children) Act 1988 which has been presented by WA Independent Senator for Nuclear Disarmament, Jo Vallentine. This act aims to prohibit the broadcasting of children's TV programmes that are violent and that promote toys modelled on characters, weapons or other war accessories which are also available for sale in Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate. The petition of the undersigned shows:
that we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers region.

Your petitioners ask that the Senate in Parliament should; halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu Conservation Zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu Stages I & II by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra Project in the national park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X-rated and Violent Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee on Video Material has concluded that ``Adverse effects upon people, and especially upon children, of exposure to material containing various degrees of violence, pornography or obscenity have been demonstrated''.
The majority of the Select Committee strongly opposed the proposition for a new NVE (non-violent erotica) category, which would have entrenched X-rated video pornography.
All six State Governments have, through their Attorneys'-General, expressed unanimous opposition to the circulation of X-rated videos.
We consider the continuing distribution of X-rated videos from the A.C.T. to be reprehensible and to be contrary to the wellbeing of the Australian community in general.
We strongly request urgent Government action to prohibit the distribution of X-rated and excessively violent video material.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland: Disaster Relief Funds
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth, that:

We are concerned that the National Party in Queensland is diverting money given by the Federal Government to the Queensland Government to alleviate natural disasters; that it might not be finding its way to its intended targets; and that it is being diverted to the coffers of the National Party itself or otherwise to expansion projects promoted by members or supporters of the National Party.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray the Federal Government be asked to legislate for an audit of account from the Queensland Government for every dollar or cent provided by the Federal Government for any type of relief operation in Queensland.

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To hold a referendum to amend the constitution so that:

The Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-
Including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-

To care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including:

To prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, the Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia humbly draws the attention of the Senate to the continued Government interference in the pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is causing hardship and confusion amongst the sick and elderly.

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded pharmaceutical benefits scheme which is free from Government tampering and provides for the public of Australia a comprehensive range of modern therapeutic products.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Vietnam: Release of Religious Prisoners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth, that
We deplore the violations of human rights being perpetrated by the Vietnamese Government, and in particular draw attention to the religious intolerance of this regime.

We call upon the Australian Government to exert its influence to request the Vietnamese Government to cease its detention, harassment and other mistreatment of thousands of buddhist monks, nuns and clerics of other religions.
We seek the assistance of the Australian Government in obtaining the release from incarceration, of religious detainees and prisoners in Vietnam.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care for the Elderly
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Embryo Experimentation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled-

The petition of the undersigned expresses concern that some scientists in Australia are intent on undertaking destructive experimentation on human embryos. This subject was examined exhaustively by the 1985-86 Senate Select Committee on Senator Harradine's Human Embryo Experimentation Bill which received 270 submissions and more than 2,000 pages of evidence. The report of the Senate Committee recommended in October 1986 that the Commonwealth Government make unlawful any destructive experiment which frustrated the development of the human embryo.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to:
Implement without delay the major recommendation of the Senate Select Committee to outlaw destructive experiments on human embryos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable The President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by cobalt 60, caesium 137, caesium 134 or any machine sources.
That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments.

We request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should ban the importation of any radioactive substances, or machinery for the purposes of food irradiation; disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in this country; ban the irradiation of food in this country; and also ban the importation of food treated by irradiation.

We ask that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, request the Government to withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. Is it a fact that Australian Federal Police (AFP) investigating the murder of Assistant Commissioner Winchester sought certain details of membership or attendance at a meeting of the Belconnen branch of the Australian Labor Party (ALP)? Is it a fact that, initially, the branch declined to cooperate with the Australian Federal Police? Is it further a fact that after the publicity of recent days there was a change of mind and access was granted? Finally, is the Minister, as a leading member of the ALP, concerned at this apparent attempt by members of his Party to impede Australian Federal Police investigations of this horrendous crime?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill will be aware, as would any other interested senator, of the facts relating to this matter because a media release was put out yesterday on behalf of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police to this effect, and I will read it in full. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mr Peter McAulay, said today (10 April) that there are no police inquiries into the Belconnen Branch of the ALP.

However, it is a fact that the AFP did approach the Belconnen Branch of the ALP shortly after Assistant Commissioner Winchester's murder to determine if certain persons had attended a certain meeting on a particular night.
That is a way of saying on the night of the murder. The media release goes on:
The Federal Police have continued to conduct a number of lines of investigation in relation to Assistant Commissioner Winchester's murder but to comment further could prejudice the investigation.

I think that puts the whole matter in proper perspective. The Federal Police have been following every possible line of inquiry in relation to this particular assassination of a senior police officer-in fact the most senior police officer to be assassinated in the Western world this century-and for that reason no stone has been left unturned in its investigative effort. That involved making an approach to the branch for assistance in looking at its attendance register. I have no reason to believe that that cooperation was not made available to the Australian Federal Police. I know for a fact that an officer of the branch, Miss Rosemary Follett, offered to make the full meeting records available for perusal by investigative officers only yesterday, but I do not believe that that was the first occasion. The fact is that the ALP branch officers have been, as I understand it-and I am going now only on media reports-very willing to assist the AFP in its inquiries in this matter. There should be no assumption that there is any wider inquiry being undertaken into the Belconnen branch of the ALP by the AFP.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: WOMEN IN THE FULL TIME WORK FORCE

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Is he aware of last month's employment figures showing continued growth in women's participation in the full time work force? Can the Minister inform the Senate how the Government's labour market reform package is assisting women's participation in the work force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be perceived by Senator Crowley in relation to my newly found responsibilities, in the absence of Senator Reynolds. The Government's record in improving women's chances of a fair go in employment is a very positive one. Almost 60 per cent of the 1.3 million jobs that have been created since this Government came to office have gone to women. In March 1989 women's full time employment increased by a further 1,600. The unemployment rate for women is now 6.7 per cent, the lowest figure since the December quarter 1976, and 4 per cent lower than when we came to office. Women's participation in the work force regularly comes in at over 50 per cent. Over 40 per cent of the labour force is female and this is regarded, I believe, by most observers as a sign of a maturing economy and not as an indictment, as Senator Walters opposite has stated on one or two occasions. Nonetheless, the Government acknowledges that work remains to be done in improving women's access to employment. Australia still has a higher gender segregated work force, with associated lower average weekly earnings for women, than some other countries.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has put in place a legislative program to try to tackle these problems. The Government also sees the achievement of equal employment opportunity for women as part of a micro-economic reform question, in particular our labour market reform package which is all about making the best possible use of human resources in the interests of Australia. The gains in efficiency that we expect to come from award restructuring and related reforms mean that women will gain access to a wider range of occupations, better advancement within occupations and improved, and a re-evaluation of, skills. To the extent that this is successful, the gains will accrue not only to women but to the economy as a whole.

Those who want women out of the work force or even refer to them as `economic conscripts', as Senator Newman and Senator Hill in one of his more aberrant moments have done, do the economy as much of a disservice as they do women. I should point out that the days are gone when the average household comprised a working husband and a wife working full time in the home caring for children. This characterises only 16.2 per cent of all income units paying tax. The Business Council of Australia stated in its recent bulletin:

The fact is . . . the majority of women want to be in the workforce, but they also do most of the child rearing, caring for the aged and domestic management. If women do have children, the combination of seeking a return on their personal investment in education and commencing a career, economic and financial circumstances and personal preferences leads most to seek re-entry to the paid work-force.

The Business Council goes on to note that enterprises which seek solutions to the difficulties faced by women seeking to re-enter the work force will have a competitive edge in the labour market. Labour market reform aims to give Australia that competitive edge, and this Government will continue to do its best to make sure that women's contribution to competitiveness is fully realised.

While that is a longer answer than I usually give, I think it is important to get this issue in perspective, which is something that the Opposition has not done. For example, Senator Newman said in March this year, `So many of these women are economic conscripts'. Senator Walters said, `For the first time under Labor this year we have 50 per cent of women in the work force. What an indictment!'. Senator Hill said something similar on 8 March, but in a notice of motion on 4 April he urged the Government vigorously to pursue programs designed to give women greater financial security and financial independence involving a number of issues, including training and worthwhile employment opportunities.

The coalition, of course, opposed the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill when it went through the Parliament in 1987. Senator Hill crossed the floor and voted against his own Party on that occasion. As usual, there is a total degree of confusion in the Opposition about these issues, and it is important that I answer the question at that length for those reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a recent press release, issued under the letterhead of Senator Irina Dunn, by a Dr Harry Recher, in which Dr Recher asserts that wildlife in the south-eastern forests of New South Wales can be protected only by the creation of new national parks, because the Forestry Commission of New South Wales has refused to implement policies suggested by his research? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this Dr Recher is in fact the same Dr Recher who, under oath in recent court actions in New South Wales, admitted that the New South Wales Forestry Commission had always incorporated his research findings into its work and had always been prepared to modify its work in line with his findings? Is this the same Dr Recher whose evidence was shown to be faulty in the Terania Creek inquiry? Would the Minister agree that Senator Dunn's involvement in the woodchip debate in southern New South Wales is based less on fact than fantasy, and that Dr Recher appears to vary his story depending on what audience he is addressing and whether or not he is under oath?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen a press release, dated 2 April, put out under the letterhead of Senator Irina Dunn and headed `Wildlife conservation not possible in south-east New South Wales without creation of new national parks immediately'. It does refer to Dr Harry Recher, who is styled as a former principal research scientist with the Australian Museum and now senior lecturer with the Department of Ecosystem Management at the University of New England. I am not in a position to query Dr Recher's credentials. He is in his own right an academic of considerable standing and status. Senator Brownhill asked me whether he is the same Dr Recher who gave evidence under oath in a court proceeding, and whose evidence was found faulty, in the Terania Creek case. I cannot actually confirm that detail directly. I assume he is the same fellow but I cannot confirm it from my own memory.

ANSWER.PARA: The whole debate about the south-east forests is moving into the realm of fantasy. I had a press conference yesterday at which I issued a press release. I think at best 1 1/2 newspapers referred to the press release in their coverage of stories that emanated from that conference. I think there is a need for a higher level of reporting on this issue so that the facts are clear. I think that is a desirable matter.

Senator Dunn's role in this debate has been quite unequivocally-in terms of her own quite strong commitment to and support of those beliefs-to argue the side of the conservation movement. I do not for one minute deny that it has a case that the community of Australia is required to listen to. I congratulate it on the way it has put its argument. However, one needs to distinguish between that case and the case that is put with equal force on the other side and the implications of simply accepting some of the wider assertions about the environment and the sawlog and woodchip industry. The livelihood of many Australians who are on low wages, poorly educated and locked into regional areas of Australia from which they have little opportunity to transfer is affected by that argument. I sympathise with those blue collar workers, given the anxiety the situation creates for their future.

This Government has been wanting to find a balanced solution to the issue, one in which the environment concerns of the area are best protected-my colleague Senator Richardson has advised me about that-one in which we protect the industry base. In that way, rather than exporting out of Australia the rawest forest product, woodchips, and buying back the most expensive forest product, paper, we could use our comparative advantage in this area and develop an indus- try approach which encourages value adding all the way down the path. That means in pulp and paper production in this country. The key to doing that is to encourage and provide sufficient incentive for Australian native hardwoods-the hardwoods in shortest supply for pulp manufacture in the world at the moment-to be put in plantations in this country so that the industry base is secured on the basis of a plantation resource.

TALK.START.PARA: —So when you have a natural base you are not going to use it, but you are going to take it away from those who could use it?

—I am coming to that point now because it is a valid point in this debate. One has to have a balanced approach to it. We are unlikely to meet the sawlog resource out of plantations in the foreseeable future. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is doing a lot of very commendable work in developing trees which grow more quickly and which enable the pulp and paper industry to have a more secure economic investment in plantations. Unfortunately, it has not yet come up with more quickly growing trees for sawlogs. I commend to the Senate the work that has been done in South Australia under the auspices of the Bannon Labor Government for the development of scrimber, a composite material made out of softwoods, not by sawing but by amalgamating together--
—CSIRO too; it invented it.

—It did, and it is being applied in South Australia. Senator Brownhill, I do not know that I have given you the joy you have sought from me by the question you have asked, but this is a serious and complex debate. To occupy extreme positions in this debate is entirely wrong. We need to obtain a result for the benefit of the Australian community which will harmonise what are apparently superficially conflicting forces so that workers in the industry can have their anxieties met, the industry has a development path and the environmental objectives can be met as well. I think that is within the wit of this Government and, with the cooperation of the New South Wales Government, within the wit of us all. That should be our objective.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. With reference to the campaign by the Royal Automobile Association of South Australia (RAA) for an increase in expenditure on roads equivalent to 2c per litre, what is the addition to outlays that that implies? Is the Government considering such an increase in expenditure on roads?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been several questions about road funding in the last few days. One of the things I note with some satisfaction is that the automobile associations around the country have finally acknowledged that there is not and should not be a one to one ratio between taxes or excise levied on fuel and Commonwealth Government expenditure on roads. I regard that as some progress.

ANSWER.PARA: The Royal Automobile Association of South Australia put out a press release last Friday defending its campaign and saying that it had never advocated spending all of the fuel excise on roads and was seeking a `modest' 2c per litre increase. That might seem to be modest, but what the Automobile Association is advocating at 2c is a very large $470m increase in Commonwealth outlays. It is also inconsistent with the Association's own official magazine, the South Australian Motor, for March and April of this year, in which the President of the RAA, Mr Bill Steele, is quoted as saying:
. . . the Government returns only five cents to roads; what we want is 7.5 cents.

That is an extra 2.5c, which amounts to a modest, or immodest, addition to outlays of $590m. The South Australian RAA also suggested that an amount equal to this could easily be found from cutting out wasteful programs. A sum of $590m is vastly in excess of the amount that Senator Michael Baume, even at the height of his antics, was able to identify as Chairman of the Waste Watch Committee by abolishing a number of little government agencies, the total amount of which added up to about $32m. Even if one agrees with Senator Baume that all those little government funded agencies should be abolished, that will give us $32m, which still leaves a long way to go to $590m.

What the South Australian RAA is in fact asking for is an increase in spending which could only be accommodated by cuts such as eliminating the $418m paid as Austudy for tertiary students plus the $200m or thereabouts paid in Austudy for secondary students. In view of all that, I am not surprised that a number of RAA members are getting pretty annoyed that their membership fees are being siphoned off into producing Liberal Party propaganda and that the chief of the RAA, Mr Fotheringham, is acting as a political mouthpiece. The last point I want to make is that the official of the South Australian RAA with whom I appeared on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation program in Adelaide yesterday pointed to the alleged very bad condition of roads in places like Cleve, Lock and Kimba on the Eyre Peninsula. Ironically, that is an agricultural area that is represented by the only National Party of Australia member for South Australia, a member of the Legislative Assembly. He represents that area. Both the National Party and the National Farmers Federation less than two years ago, as Senator Stone well knows, were advocating that less Commonwealth money should be spent on roads and not more.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the second question, which was whether the property was bought at auction by a man with children rather than openly by the CAA, I am advised that the CAA used an agent to purchase the land and bid at the auction. As the auction price did not reach the reserve, the agent entered into negotiations with the vendor and at that stage revealed his connection with the CAA.

The answer to the third and fourth questions is no. As regards the fifth question, as indicated in response to the first, the property is to be used for the siting of a secondary surveillance radar. I am advised that the CAA has undertaken extensive analysis of suitable sites in the Mount Lofty Ranges. This site has been identified as the most suitable available. However, following a community consultation meeting last Friday, 7 April, with CAA officers, a committee of local residents has been formed, and they will be examining a number of alternative sites with the CAA.

As to the seventh question, which was whether this development is part of $100m expenditure on radar facilities here and in other parts of Australia, the radar sensor procurement program involving an expenditure of over $100m will see the replacement and extension of the Australian radar network with 19 new radar installations extending from Cairns to Perth. As regards the eighth question, like all Commonwealth statutory authorities, the CAA is not directly bound by State and local government planning regulations. Ninthly, in accordance with the Act to which I have just referred, a notice of intent is being prepared. It is a matter for the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to decide whether an EIS is required. The answer to the tenth question is yes.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a letter which appeared in yesterday's Australian Financial Review written by Mr John Simmonds, Federal Secretary of the Post Office Agents Association? Does the Minister agree with Mr Simmonds that there ought to be a tax incentive for workers not covered by occupational superannuation schemes to make private provision for their retirement income needs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the letter and I agree with the basic points that Mr Simmonds makes. Mr Simmonds, however, appears to be unaware of the fact that there is already such an incentive. It was substantially increased with effect from 1 July last year. At that time the ceiling on tax deductable contributions by the self-employed and also employees not covered by employer sponsored funds under section 82aa of the Income Tax Assessment Act was increased from the previous $1,500 to $3,000. That means that a self-employed person with an income of around $27,000, which is just above average weekly earnings, can put $3,000 of that income into one of the various superannuation schemes, claiming the whole $3,000 as a deduction from that taxable income, and then be taxed on the remaining $24,000. That essentially puts him or her in an equivalent position as that of a wage or salary earner on a taxable income of $24,000 whose employer is making a contribution to a funded superannuation scheme at a rate of 12 1/2 per cent of wages or salaries.

ANSWER.PARA: I think I am safe in saying that there are not very many funded schemes to which employers contribute at a rate higher than 12 1/2 per cent. If the hypothetical self-employed person chooses to put more than $3,000 into a super scheme, the money over and above that $3,000 is not deductable from the taxable income at the time but it is exempt from the 15 per cent tax levied on employer contributions to super schemes. In other words, it is treated in exactly the same way as are employee contributions to occupational superannuation schemes.

What I have said in regard to self-employed persons applies in the same way to employees whose employers do not provide them with any employer sponsored occupational super other than the 3 per cent productivity money. As I said at the beginning, I agree with the conclusions to which Mr Simmonds has come but clearly he is not fully aware of the facts. I will see that he does become aware of the facts and suggest that he alert the members of his Association to these substantial superannuation savings incentives which are already part of the income tax system.

—I refer the Minister for Consumer Affairs to the report released yesterday by the Economic Planning Advisory Council (EPAC) titled Economic and Social Implications of Consumer Debt. Is it a fact that the report indicates that 100,000 Australian families are facing bankruptcy? What steps is the Government taking to address the problem of overcommitment on consumer credit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fact that the EPAC paper addresses the essential question of consumer debt. It is very much within the framework of this Government to provide an environment in which the problems of consumers facing overcommitment can be responded to in a very constructive way. This paper follows the forum run by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council in Canberra last year, which also produced a number of positive policy development outcomes. It is unfortunate that in reporting the EPAC report a number of media outlets have chosen to ignore discussion on the report, to ignore the findings of the report and to make a very basic, confused mistake between overcommitment and bankruptcy. It is not right to claim that the report indicates that 100,000 Australian families will go bankrupt. It should be noted that at the peak of the increase in bankruptcies, bankruptcies caused by consumer debt totalled less than 10,000 per annum. In fact, bankruptcy has been declining and it is pleasing for me to able to announce today that figures I have just seen indicate a 22.8 per cent decrease in the number of bankrupts for the quarter ending March this year as opposed to those for the same quarter last year. There has been a 14.7 per cent decrease in the number of bankruptcies for the nine months to March this year compared with the same period last year.

ANSWER.PARA: It should also be noted that in commenting in this way the media have managed to ignore essential parts of the report which indicate that consumer debt did peak in 1986, after a steady increase in the early 1980s, but has fallen over the past two years. It should also be recognised that a substantial cause for this decrease has been the employment policies of this Government. Unemployment was 50 per cent higher in 1983-84 than it is now, according to the March figures for this year. Employment has increased by 1.3 million people over that period under this Government.

Despite the amelioration in the situation, the Government's job has not ended. EPAC has raised a number of issues which are already being acted upon by the Government. In the area of financial counselling, training and education I have already mentioned in this place the proposal to organise industry funding to assist financial counsellors in those essential functions of training and education. We have already passed legislation in this Parliament to amend the Bankruptcy Act to ensure that a one week moratorium is introduced so that those who intend to go bankrupt get advice from financial counsellors before they do so. Another part of the report deals with the whole question of consumer awareness campaigns. This Government is embarking upon a process to target those disadvantaged sections of our community, particularly youth, in terms of gearing education to them.

Another major issue which EPAC mentions is the adequacy of State credit legislation. In fact, this issue has been one of my highest priorities in the last 12 months. Last year State and Federal Ministers for Consumer Affairs discussed-and this year they will continue to discuss-a concept of uniform legislation to cover the consumer credit area. To date, we have legislation which covers only the regulation of finance companies, but does not cover the banking sector, credit unions and building societies. It is the intention of all Ministers to ensure that by July this year we come up with an approach which not only gives us uniformity in legislation but also gives a significant extension to consumer rights in those areas which I have mentioned.

So, in summary, it is fair to say that the indication in the report that 100,000 Australian families are going bankrupt is not right. But it is also fair to say that the Government's policies are very much geared towards addressing this problem in a constructive way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade seen a recent claim that there now has been no war for 44 consecutive years between major nations of the developed world-the longest period, it is claimed, since the days of the Roman Empire? Does the Minister agree with this analysis which discounts the claimed dominant role of nuclear weapons in deterring war? Does the Minister accept the claim that even conventional war now is perceived by major nations to be both repulsive and futile? What, if any, are the major threats seen by the Australian Government to continued world peace between major developed nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to ask my colleague, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, whether it is in fact the longest period without major direct conflict since the days of the Roman Empire. Certainly, it is the case that there has been no direct conflict between the major nations of the developed world since 1945. It is also the case that these nations, in common with Australia, would today certainly perceive this kind of war, like any war, as both repulsive and futile. This is not to say, of course, that we now live in a peaceful world. Indeed, many of these nations have been directly and indirectly engaged in other conflicts over that period.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of major threats to the status quo, to which Senator Maguire referred, it is important to recognise the difference between the irrationality and the possibility of war. There still exist large, professional infrastructures devoted to defence, and while these exist political disputes between nations, including those of the developed world, always risk leading to war. This consideration accounts for the Australian Government's very active role in encouraging the major powers to agree on substantial arms reductions which still retain stability in both their nuclear and conventional forces.

The best hope of significantly extending the period in which there have been no major wars between developed nations is to encourage nations to recognise the substantial risks inherent in the use of force-that is something I wish the Liberal Opposition would have regard to, with its cavalier approach to many of these issues and its gung-ho encouragement of activity-and to concentrate on advancing national interests and strengthening stability based on international cooperation on security and arms control issues.

So far as our own position is concerned, we currently enjoy, as has been said in various places, not least in the White Paper by my colleague Mr Beazley, a favourable security outlook with no identifiable military threat. We certainly cannot give ourselves over to the rosy view taken by some people in this chamber that unilateral disarmament could increase our security. Our defence planning continues to give priority to defending Australia against the kind of military pressure that could arise in the shorter term.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH SCIENTIFIC AND INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH ORGANISATION: STAFF

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of media reports which indicate that the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) will need to shed 500 staff over the next three years and that the organisation faces a budget shortfall of $14.2m next year? Are these issues related? Furthermore, do they indicate that the Opposition is right in calling for a parliamentary inquiry into the CSIRO to sort out its budgetary problems and to give the organisation direction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am certainly aware of all those media reports that Senator Giles refers to in her question. Furthermore, I am well aware of some of the underlying issues. In answer to the first part of the question, the shedding of staff does not follow from the budget shortfall in CSIRO. It does, however, arise from fundamental changes resulting from strategic decisions taken by the CSIRO board and management. The structure and charter of CSIRO has been comprehensively reviewed over the past few years. In 1986, the Government amended the Organisation's enabling Act to reflect contemporary requirements for a primarily government funded research body. The Organisation itself engaged McKinsey and Co. Inc. to examine its role and structure. The resulting changes have a focus of a much more responsive and business-oriented organisation. An examination of the Organisation's administrative structure and systems has also been undertaken and implement- ation is almost complete.

ANSWER.PARA: The strategic decision which has been taken by CSIRO management will allow CSIRO to deploy its internal resources in a similar manner to the best overseas laboratories, and is a long overdue reform of critical importance to CSIRO's operational flexibility. A $14.2m budget shortfall for 1988-89 has come to light as a result of the implementation of improved costing and accounting procedures within CSIRO. The present problems within CSIRO are as a result of its adaptation to long term trends, not political issues of the day. They are well understood by all Ministers who have the CSIRO, as well as wider science and technology issues, under scrutiny at the present time.

While I am on my feet, I point out that this issue and the public debate about this issue are not helped by the sorts of statements emanating from the Opposition. For example, on 9 March, two shadow Ministers put out statements relating to CSIRO. One was from Mr Julian Beale, who is described on his letterhead as the `Shadow Minister for Education'. Mr Beale said:
The federal Government must release the Report to Cabinet by Science Minister, Barry Jones, calling for greatly increased science funding . . .
There is no report to Cabinet. Mr Beale's statement continued:
The Cabinet . . . rejected the Jones request.
whatever it is said to have been. That is not correct. He continued:
Jones and the Science Department-
There is no Science Department and there has not been one for two years. One would have thought that a shadow Minister might have been aware of that. He continued:
. . . had asked especially for increased funding of biotechnology, water and soil conservation, and superconductivity.
That is not correct. That statement is totally incorrect. He said:
This panic move follows disagreements on policy between Mr Jones, Mr Dawkins and Senator Button.

There is no disagreement on policy of a fundamental kind. On the same day, Mr McGauran, who does describe himself as Opposition spokesman on science and energy, had a fair bit to say, which is pretty distinct from what Mr Beale was saying that day. Mr McGauran is advocating a parliamentary committee which `would have the vital task of rewriting the charter so that it ensures a supportive political working environment for the organisation'-that is, CSIRO-`and its responsibilities'. He goes on to say that the committee would `make some critical decisions about the future of scientific research work in Australia'.

It is the Government's view, and it was also the view of the Fraser Government, that it is not government business to make detailed critical decisions about science and the directions of science. That is why governments of each political persuasion have provided a one-line appropriation for CSIRO and invested in it and its management the responsibility for making decisions about the scientific directions of the Organisation. As usual the Opposition's statements on this issue represent a degree of confusion and, sadly, ignorance, which is alarming for anybody who might at some stage in a year or so--

TALK.START.PARA: —The agony is oozing out.

—There is a lot of agony oozing out. It is alarming that these highly paid people sitting on the Opposition benches should wallow in such a degree of ignorance about simple matters like the departments of State which exist in Australia and what the priorities of various departments of State are.

—Is the Minister for Finance aware of the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures, which show that there has been a dramatic increase in investor activity since the re-introduction of negative gearing-from 9.4 per cent of all finance provided for housing in the September quarter of 1987 to 20.7 per cent in the December quarter of 1988? Is the Minister further aware that in raw figures this is a total increase in investor finance from $121.2m to $443.6m, which breaks down to an increase in purchase finance for existing dwellings from $68.6m to $302.6m-an increase of almost five times-and an increase in construction finance from $52.6m to only $141m-an increase of only three times? Does the Minister agree that this shows clearly that investors are largely using negative gearing to displace home buyers, not to build new housing? Is the Minister concerned with the effects of this negative gearing exercise which the Government set in place with the concurrence of the Opposition-effects which are demonstrated by the December quarter figures from the Victorian Department of Housing and Construction `Rental Report', which show that in the 12 months from December 1987 rentals increased by almost twice the inflation rate in Victoria? Will the Minister concede that negative gearing has clearly failed as a means of resolving the housing crisis by resulting in a displacement of intending home buyers with speculating investors? Will the Government commit itself before the Greensborough by-election in Victoria next Saturday, where the housing crisis is a major concern, to abolishing this rort for property speculators?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to keep the answer shorter than the question but I will probably not succeed because there are a number of points which need to be made. Senator Powell, or someone from her staff, dropped this question into my office at about 12.30 today. The figures that she cited on finance provided for housing during the September quarter show an increase from 9.4 per cent to 20.7 per cent. Nobody in my office has been able to find any figures in any official publication that are equal to those, or any category or classification that is clearly identifiable or can be matched with that description. I cannot really comment on the figures per se, but assuming the figures mean something--
—That is a pretty heroic assumption.

—Perhaps it is a pretty heroic assumption, but it appears that the figures did not come from the ABS; perhaps they came from the fairy at the bottom of the garden. Whatever the correct figures are-if the categories are accurately described-they appear to relate to finance for housing, allegedly for negative gearing or for investment but not for construction. In other words, there is a turnover component in this which does not affect the total stock of housing.

ANSWER.PARA: The other point which ought to be made is that, without wishing to be too disrespectful, the Australian Democrats are always attracted to conspiracy theories of various types. A minor variant of the conspiracy theory here is that people who want to be home buyers are being displaced by people who are buying properties for rental. If that is true-I do not know whether it is true-it means by definition that more housing is available for rental, and not only available for rental but it is being rented. By definition, to take advantage of negative gearing the owner of a property must have a tenant. If there are losers on the buyer side of the market there will be gainers on the rental side. Frankly, I do not know how that all balances out, but I suggest that Senator Powell, before she asks questions like this again, should source the figures which are stated in her questions and try to describe what she is talking about somewhat more accurately than the subjects that are described in this question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I wish to ask Senator Walsh whether ministerial staff numbers are so depleted in these days of economic cut-backs that one hour and 15 minutes notice is not enough for staff to follow up an ABS publication number provided to his staff before Question Time, as it was in this case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of being accused of boring the Senate, I will repeat the first part of Senator Powell's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister for Finance aware of the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures-
not specified, no catalogue number given, no description other than `Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures'-

which show that there has been a dramatic increase in investor activity since the re-introduction of negative gearing-from 9.4 per cent of all finance provided for housing in the September quarter of 1987 to 20.7 per cent in the December quarter of 1988?

Medical practitioners were provided with advance notice of the de-listing of the 12 brands from the pharmaceutical benefits scheme list in the December 1988 schedule of the pharmaceutical benefits. However, they would not have been fully informed of the circumstances surrounding the de-listing, including the fact that alternative brands remaining on the subsidised list have been subject to the same stringent standards of government testing as the de-listed products.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government was reluctantly forced into undertaking an advertising campaign on this issue in an endeavour to counteract a campaign of misinformation being waged by the pharmaceutical industry and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. Because of the fear and uncertainty generated by these vested financial interests, the Government had a clear responsibility to inform the elderly and chronically ill through their health care professionals of all the facts on the delisting of the 12 brands and to allay concerns about the availability and efficacy of the alternative brands still listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The information capsule, which was distributed to 26,000 medical practitioners throughout Australia, cost $45,000, including packaging, collating, labelling and postage. The unit cost was $1.73. The capsule method of distribution was selected ahead of conventional envelope distribution on the advice of the advertising agency consulting to the Government on this campaign, which considered the capsule more likely to attract the attention of busy medical practitioners and therefore ensure that the Government's message on this issue was effectively communicated. It is pointed out that the drug industry in Australia spends an estimated $3m per week on drug promotion and product information, directed mostly at general practitioners. A conventional envelope would have been unlikely to penetrate the plethora of written material received by doctors.
