TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I make this statement on the administration of Aboriginal affairs on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Honourable senators will recall that in November last year the Government announced a number of interrelated inquiries into the administration of Aboriginal affairs. The background to the establishment of these inquiries was material provided and statements made in Senate Estimates Committee processes, and elsewhere, alleging serious shortcomings in the administration, including financial management, in the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) and in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) announced on 7 November 1988 that he had asked the Auditor-General to undertake a comprehensive audit of the Aboriginal Development Commission and to extend this, as appropriate, to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. He announced also that the Public Service Commissioner would be investigating questions concerning personnel management in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and that the Department of Finance would investigate any staff classification issues. Furthermore, he announced that the Government recognised that certain matters might still require further examination in the light of these specialised investigations and that the Government had asked Mr Andrew Menzies, AM, OBE, a former deputy secretary of the Attorney-General's Department, to make any such inquiry.

The Auditor-General and the Public Service Commissioner are, of course, independent statutory officers, and the Government made it clear that Mr Menzies would also be exercising an independent role in following up any outstanding matters. The Government also made it clear that each of these inquiries should be as thorough as those conducting them judged necessary. It was the Government's intention from the outset that, in the light of the outcome of these inquiries, it would consider whatever steps might be necessary to address any problems brought to light.

I am now able to advise honourable senators that most of these various inquiries have been completed. The Public Service Commissioner and the Department of Finance have completed their inquiries. Moreover, as a result of a further request from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), the Department of Finance has prepared a broader report on financial management in the Aboriginal Development Commission. As honourable senators already know, the Auditor-General has completed a substantial part of his remit, with only a report on some particular enterprise projects in the Aboriginal Development Commission area which were brought to notice in the Senate yet to come.

Mr Menzies has completed an interim report which outlines the process he is following in his inquiries and the matters which he has excluded. In particular, he is not re-examining issues which have been dealt with definitively by the Public Service Commissioner, the Department of Finance or the Auditor-General in their reports. Mr Menzies has identified two issues in the Auditor-General's report which have not been or are not being dealt with to finality by the Auditor-General and which Mr Menzies sees as appropriate for his investigation. He indicates that these two matters are under active investigation, together with a comparatively small number of matters arising from submissions received from the public or otherwise brought to his attention. Mr Menzies outlines in part II of his interim report the matters under investigation but recommends that that part of the report not be published generally. The Government accepts his recommendations that, in view of the continuing investigations, part II should not be published. It has, however, been made available to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney) and the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines).

I make the important point that, pending Mr Menzies' final report, I shall not comment today upon the conduct of any individual, nor should others prejudge the findings. Attempts to ascribe guilt by allegation or smear are simply unacceptable. The Government also has, of course, the recommendations and views of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. The Government is confident, therefore, that the primary issues of administration in the area of Aboriginal affairs have been covered in all the reports we have now received. Against this background, I now table in the Senate all the reports referred to excepting the Auditor-General's report which has already been tabled and part II of Mr Menzies' report.

With the bulk of the inquiries now completed, the Government is in a position to inform the Parliament of its views and intentions concerning organisational arrangements for the Aboriginal affairs portfolio on the basis of thorough consideration of the material now available to us. The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), who is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will be following me with a detailed statement concerning these arrangements. The Government, of course, stands ready to refine its response and undertake any further action, should that be necessary, when the remaining reports are received. They will, of course, also be tabled in the Parliament.

At the outset it needs to be acknowledged that administrative shortcomings, some of them serious, are evident in the area of Aboriginal administration. The Government does not sweep aside these shortcomings, nor will we shirk our responsibility to correct them. In the case of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Auditor-General found that, overall, there was a lower than acceptable standard of administration. Clearly, administrative practices in a wide range of areas will have to be tightened. The Government recognises this, the Department knows it and some steps have been taken already.

The Department of Finance concluded, in relation to staff classification matters, that the action taken by the Department was not well founded in terms of classification principles and processes. Honourable senators should note in this regard that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has accepted the Department of Finance's conclusions and the necessity of appropriate corrective action. On the other hand, I believe it is important to note that, as the Auditor-General's and Public Service Commissioner's inquiries found, some of the more vocal critics of the Department were unable to provide evidence to back their claims. The Public Service Commissioner has not substantiated allegations of patronage, favouritism, nepotism and cronyism in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. No hard evidence was produced that would warrant investigation under the Public Service Act.

The Public Service Commissioner's delegate, Mr H. B. MacDonald, found no more than that there was an occasional lack of prudence or judgment and that there were some deficiencies in the Department's personnel practices, most particularly an inordinate delay in approving an equal employment opportunity program. Mr MacDonald also concluded that it was essential to clarify the policy guidelines on Aboriginalisation-that is, enhancing access by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to employment in the Department. The much more fundamental problems brought to light in these inquiries are in the programs administered by the Aboriginal Development Commission rather than the Department.

The special audit report's major criticisms are directed at the way the Aboriginal Development Commission administers its enterprise funds-pointing to a number of failed enterprises and less than rigorous oversight by the Commission. In nearly all cases mentioned in the report, Audit found that the ADC had failed to apply the criteria set out in its legislation and concluded that the most serious defects in administration were in the ADC's approval procedures.

It should also be noted that there are proposals in the broader Department of Finance report for a strengthening of administrative support in these areas and for the exercise of greater control, through clearer and more specific ministerially endorsed guidelines. The Government has taken these findings into account in the response which I shall outline and on which Senator Tate's statement will elaborate.

Before outlining the Government's response to the findings of these inquiries, it is essential that I reaffirm the two basic principles at stake in this crucial area of government administration. There is, first, the imperative for self-management, by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, of government programs designed to assist their well-being. If there is one lesson that emerges from 200 years of contact between the original inhabitants of this country and the Europeans who have arrived since 1788, it is this: that after all the benign neglect, the paternalism and the failed attempts at assimilation, today we realise that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders themselves are the best judges of their needs and priorities. In recent years, the imperative of self-management has received considerable bipartisan support and it is one to which this Government has shown its fundamental commitment.

Secondly, there is the thoroughly complementary imperative for proper ministerial responsibility and accountability for, and effective parliamentary scrutiny of, programs as a whole, especially in relation to their financial administration. The nub of the issue before us then is finding the right balance between the principles of self-management and of overall ministerial responsibility. Many critics, including in the Senate, fail to see the need for balance. They have drawn the facile conclusion that answers to the administrative shortcomings that have been identified, especially in the Aboriginal Development Commission, lie solely in winding back self-management.

The Government believes it is possible-indeed, it is vital-to strike a better balance; a balance that both widens and deepens the opportunity for self-management, and establishes a more appropriate means of financial accountability and ministerial oversight. That is precisely what the Government's proposed legislation for the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) seeks to achieve. It seeks to widen the scope for Aboriginal self-management to encompass all of the programs undertaken within portfolio agencies, and to deepen its real effectiveness by giving Aboriginal people at a regional and local level a far more specific responsibility to determine priorities and outcomes. It seeks also to establish the right mechanism for ministerial involvement which will genuinely uphold the principle of accountability to the broader Australian community.

I take this opportunity to reaffirm the Government's determination to proceed with the ATSIC legislation. Nothing that has emerged from these inquiries has eroded the Government's fundamental support for the concept and nature of ATSIC. But we can and will draw on the work of the Senate Committee and on the inquiries to refine and improve the details. In his statement today Senator Tate will describe the Government's intentions on amendments to the ATSIC legislation, particularly in the light of the report of the Senate Select Committee.

I believe it is appropriate in this context to remind honourable senators of some of the legislative history of Aboriginal self-management, and in particular to point out that ADC itself was developed, under the previous Government, with a less than conventional level of ministerial oversight for a statutory authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all make mistakes.

—I begin by quoting the words of Senator Neville Bonner, the first Aboriginal member of parliament, in giving, on behalf of the previous Government, the second reading speech on the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill in the Senate on 21 November 1979. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government, in introducing the Aboriginal Development Commission Bill, is taking steps to put into effect what I have been saying for a number of years-the placing into Aboriginal hands of the control of Aboriginal affairs.
He went on to say:
. . . Aboriginals will be responsible for the decision-making. Of course this is not to say that Aboriginals also will not make mistakes.
I interpolate here to say to Senator Stone that he is continually being acknowledged in this statement. Senator Bonner went on to say:

It is to be expected that we will, as we all do. But Aboriginals should have greater sensitivity to Aboriginal needs and they will learn from any mistakes they make while exercising this responsibility.

As honourable senators will know, the legislation to establish the ADC was not actually passed until 1980. The amended legislation, again in the words of Senator Bonner, was designed to `strengthen the commitment to self-management' and to achieve `further steps down the road to making equality a reality for Aboriginal Australians'. He was able to say that because the weight of the responses to the original Bill was to reduce the role of the Minister and expand the role of the Commission. I would also remind honourable senators of some important points made in that 1980 Senate debate by Senator Chaney, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. He said:
. . . there is an element of risk in Aboriginal self-management. I think it is a risk which both the previous Government and this Government have seen as a worthwhile risk.
He also said:

I suggest to those members of the Opposition who are concerned, that they look at the limitations of ministerial power in this Bill as compared to the Bills that the Opposition when in government put through the Parliament in 1974 and 1975.

I think they will see that we are progressing in the way that one would expect towards withdrawing ministerial authority. I do not suggest that the Bills that were passed in 1974 were wrong for their time. I suggest that, as one would expect, we are moving in a direction of increasing Aboriginal control rather than ministerial control.

The significance of this recital of the background to the ADC is that it shows that both sides of the Parliament have made, and welcomed, moves to give Aboriginals a greater say in the design and delivery of programs to advance their status in Australian society. We all have been prepared to accept what Senator Chaney termed `an element of risk'.

In reaffirming my Government's support for ATSIC I make the point that, given this legislative history, the proposed new Commission is the logical and appropriate next step for the advancement of both the great principles of self-management and ministerial accountability. Not only do the reports of the inquiries not undermine the Government's belief that ATSIC represents the correct way forward-we are encouraged by some of the positive implications for ATSIC's basic structure in the inquiry reports. For example, the special audit report illustrates the problems which can arise when one agency, the Aboriginal Development Commission, confuses its activities in enterprise funding with its own wider socio-economic responsibilities, and those of other agencies. It also points up some difficulties the Department of Aboriginal Affairs has experienced in providing a balanced range of services to communities in response to their expressed needs.

While the report does not draw any conclusions, the Government notes that such problems as these would be reduced by bringing the full range of programs under a single administration, by eliminating the potential for overlap, and by planning systematically on the basis of communities' and regions' own priorities. At the same time, the Government accepts that it cannot proceed with these changes without addressing as effectively as possible the administrative shortcomings brought to light in the various inquiries, and the need for accountability and appropriate ministerial involvement and parliamentary scrutiny.

The Government had already, in the development of the ATSIC Bill, sought to provide for greater ministerial involvement-through the Minister being able to establish guidelines within which the new body would be required to operate in the administration of policies and programs, and being closely involved in the monitoring of priority setting through approval of estimates on a regional basis. These controls are designed to prevent the possibility of any radical departures from the approved estimates and policy goals.

Honourable senators will note that the Department of Finance report tabled today recommends that the Minister should be given a broad role to approve the estimates of the Aboriginal Development Commission; should consult on the Commission's corporate plan; and should issue broad policy guidelines, especially where financial administration is concerned. The ATSIC legislation which the Government is proposing will meet those requirements.

We have, moreover, considered to what extent the thrust of those recommendations should apply to the ADC while it continues to function in the lead up to ATSIC, as the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will indicate in his statement. Also relevant is the recommendation made by the Auditor-General that the Government review the business enterprise provisions in the ATSIC Bill. The Government has done so and a more detailed statement covering its consideration of both the general financial accountability and business enterprise provisions of the Bill will be made by Senator Tate.

The Government has also determined that it will respond to the problems raised in the various inquiry reports, and to the suggestions made by the Public Service Commissioner for strengthened support, in the following ways. We will amend the ATSIC legislation to establish an Office of Evaluation and Audit, details of which will be provided in Senator Tate's statement. We will ensure that there are adequate resources provided to the new Commission to enable these audit and reporting functions to be carried out effectively. We will make sure that there are sufficient resources, including for training and by way of a temporary infusion of specialist managerial skills, for the new Commission. The Public Service Commissioner's reports pointed to the need for better training and improved management practices, and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is discussing with the Public Service Commissioner the best way to implement those recommendations in the Department as it is now. Dr McIver, in her report last year, as consultant on the new Commission's staffing and administrative structure, also concluded that a very active staff development program would be vital in the Commission's early days.

Because the reports have highlighted the need for training Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who work in community organisations, if they are to function with proper financial management, the Government will look to how it can intensify its efforts under the Aboriginal organisations training program. More immediately, the Government recognises the need to spell out and clarify the policy of Aboriginalisation for specific staffing positions concerned with formulation of policy for, and direct delivery of services to, Aboriginals, especially within the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the new Commission. We will require relevant Commonwealth agencies to establish-in consultation with the Public Service Commissioner and relevant unions-policy guidelines on enhancing access by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to employment, and that appropriate equal employment opportunity plans be in place on the establishment of ATSIC.

It would not be appropriate to conclude this statement without making mention of those many people whose diligence and commitment to the cause of the Aboriginal people cannot be questioned. The efforts of so many of these Australians, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal alike-including those in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Aboriginal Development Commission-are beyond the demands of duty. Indeed, some of the shortcomings that have been identified have arisen, not from base motives, but from a genuine determination to overcome the appalling disadvantage suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is as a result of those efforts, over very many years, that government-sponsored programs are gradually improving the health, housing, education and employment of Aboriginal Australians and are steadily strengthening Aboriginal communities through land rights, through enterprise development, and through the provision of services to improve basic living conditions. My Government is proud that, in recognition of this vitally important work, we have continued to make substantial real increases in allocations to Aboriginal programs in an era when it has been necessary to wind back the growth in overall Commonwealth expenditure.

The inquiries have submitted the administration of Aboriginal affairs to an extraordinarily detailed scrutiny and produced a wealth of material and analysis in a relatively short time frame. The Government appreciates the effort of all of the agencies and people involved, and I take this opportunity to thank them for it. Surely the time has now come, especially in this Parliament, to cease the constant stream of allegation which has dogged this vital area of government administration. The Government's approach is, as I have indicated, to draw upon lessons from the inquiries and to look to the future-to ensure that mechanisms are put in place and support provided so that future administration is on a sound footing. We are determined to address administrative problems in a way which ensures a higher quality of future administration in this very important area of government and, in the long run, a higher quality of life and sense of belonging for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement, and condemns the Government and the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs for their failures in the administration of Aboriginal affairs, and calls on the Government to delay further consideration of the ATSIC proposals until there has been full and effective consultation with the Aboriginal community and the rest of the Australian community and a remedying of existing administrative shortcomings.

We have before us today a vast array of both statements and reports. Those statements first started to arrive in my office at 1.20 p.m., and the last of the statements arrived at 1.40 p.m. I saw some of the reports at an even later time. I therefore have to acknowledge that a close reading of all of these documents has not been possible for me, but I have certainly had a chance to read the statements which have been put down and the statement that has just been read by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in this place. I wish to express my very great disappointment and the disappointment of the Opposition at the announcement which is contained in the statement delivered on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), that the Government intends and is determined to proceed with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner (ATSIC) legislation.

Before going on to deal with that particular matter, may I record some satisfaction at the fact that the Government has, in the various statements which have been put down, acknowledged the value of the work of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. I do that because honourable senators will recall that this was a matter of very considerable contention. In fact, on 15 February this year the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, made a very substantial attack on the Senate committee system in general and on the Senate Committee looking at ATSIC in particular. He said things like this:
Civil liberties of those individuals are just swept aside, while some Senators strut around this country . . . floating on their own ego picking up these sorts of wild stories . . .
He went on to say:

And so I say to the Senate committee, you know, anything that they suggest, any proposition they put up-because it is a stunt, the whole thing's been a political stunt-doesn't automatically mean that I'm going to accept it.

I remind the Senate of those words because today the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, through the mouth of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, has indicated that the Government has accepted the vast majority of the recommendations of the majority of the Committee. In other words, the majority report of the Committee-which is in the main a report of all of the senators, although there is a strong dissenting report on a number of particular matters from Senator Boswell and Senator Peter Baume-the main detail of the recommendations of this Committee, have in fact now been picked up and adopted by the Government. I make the point that the cheap and vicious political attack which was made on the Senate Committee has now been exposed for what it was, because the Minister and the Government have now affirmed the bulk of those recommendations.

This statement of the Prime Minister's is something of a confession of fault, yet at the same time an ignoring of the faults and problems which have been disclosed. What the Prime Minister has just said, through the mouth of Senator Button, is that it needs to be acknowledged that administrative shortcomings, some of them serious, are evident in the area of Aboriginal administration. The Prime Minister went on to say:
The Government does not sweep aside these shortcomings nor will we shirk our responsibility to correct them.

What has happened, in fact, is that all of these problems and shortcomings have been reduced to the neatness of these reports. We have managed to get down in black and white what they are, and they make extremely sorry reading. We are told that remedial action will be taken by the Government with respect to these matters, but the fact is that remedial action has not yet been taken.

I want to take the Senate behind these neat, green bound reports. I suggest, Madam Acting Deputy President, that you take your colleague the Prime Minister to Balgo and Wiluna, preferably on pension day, as I have been to Wiluna on pension day, and I suggest that you talk to your colleague the State Minister for Aboriginal Affairs about the concerns that are being expressed to her about the condition of the administration of Aboriginal affairs in your and my State of Western Australia, and the disgraceful confusion in so many of those areas which are so neatly now written about, typed and bound in these reports.

Madam Acting Deputy President, there is a fundamental internal inconsistency in what Senator Button, on behalf of his and your Prime Minister, has put down today. We are told that it is the determination of the Government to proceed with a proposal which, the Opposition believes, does not have the support of even the Australian Labor Party. It has the support of the Prime Minister and Minister Hand. The only reason ATSIC is proceeding is that there is not sufficient interest in the field of Aboriginal affairs for the Labor Party, which has the responsibility for the Government in this place, to intervene and to take this matter out of the hands of a Prime Minister who is self-indulgent and who simply parades himself on the Aboriginal affairs stage, a Prime Minister who, in my view, has shamefully sold out the Aboriginal people of Australia at the same time as he has pretended to champion their cause. On page 7 of the statement that we have before us the Prime Minister said:

At the same time, the Government accepts that it cannot proceed with these changes without addressing as effectively as possible the administrative shortcomings brought to light in the various inquiries, and the need for accountability and appropriate ministerial involvement and parliamentary scrutiny.

I accuse the Prime Minister of inconsistency because the simple truth is that it is not possible to put an orderly administration in place on top of the chaos which at present exists. The first and simple responsibility of the Government in Aboriginal affairs in 1989 is to get some order into the existing administration. I am appalled by the reports which I get from Aboriginal communities about the breakdown of administration. I am appalled by the statements made by people in the Aboriginal Development Commission. I was invited to take tea with them during the last parliamentary recess. They told me they were demoralised, that they were unable to do their task and that it would take years to restore orderly administration. I am appalled by the fact that when one meets a departmental officer in a casual way at an airport or wherever almost inevitably today the talk is of demoralisation and an incapacity to do the task. I laugh at some of these reports. Some of these reports simply reflect the fact that people are frightened and are not prepared to speak in an open way. There is plenty that is being said. There is nobody who is even vaguely close to the administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs who would not believe that the administration is in chaos.

We are not talking about some chaos in a government department which, of itself, would not matter, except it would be a matter of waste. We are talking about the sort of chaos which means that children are not nourished or educated and that the next generation of Aboriginal people are being condemned to a worse life in many communities than they had in the last generation. That is what we are debating. It is simply not true that the Government is putting in place a procedure which will be more accountable.

If one wanted to design an arrangement which was based on building on the mistakes of the past so as to repeat them one could not have done a better job than Minister Hand. I used to say that there was nothing right about Minister Hand except that his heart was in the right place. I withdraw that comment. I withdraw it because I have been assured by somebody who has worked closely with Minister Hand that that is the only serious mistake I have made in my comments in this area. The scurrilous way that Minister Hand has attacked anybody who has challenged what he is so thoughtlessly and recklessly doing without the benefit of steady advice-just as his Prime Minister has been reckless-and the pathetic and stupid and arrogant way that this Minister has behaved is a disgrace to the Labor Party and to this Government. The truth is that Minister Hand has now accepted-presumably because that is the price of getting legislation through the Senate, for which he requires the support of the Australian Democrats-that there will be a need to very substantially amend this legislation. I think that without doubt the Opposition will have very many more substantial amendments to offer which we will debate in this place.

I ask the Australian Democrats to look at the prospect of the timetable that the Minister has put in place for the establishment of ATSIC. I ask the Australian Democrats to look at the proposition that there should be a temporary five-man commission to run this show. I ask them whether they can in conscience support the timetable or the interim proposal that the Minister has put forward. The timetable is clearly not realistic. The suggestion that ATSIC should be in place by November is absurd. We could not possibly deal with the legislation in the program which the Government has put before us. The Government does not intend to have the legislation before us until June. I am not sure at what time in June or July it wishes us to adjourn. The fact is that we are expected to go into some sort of interim administration of ATSIC by November, as I understand from the statements before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —October.

—I am corrected by Senator Tambling. I thank him for his assistance. The fact is that this is again a political timetable. It has nothing to do with the orderly administration of Aboriginal affairs. We in the Opposition are in the unhappy position of having to rely upon the good sense and integrity of the Australian Democrats in examining this proposal. I say to them that they will carry a very heavy responsibility. I make the utterly confident assertion after 30 years of involvement in this area of policy and involvement with the Aboriginal community that this legislation is laying the framework for the next shambles. In five years' time the Senate will be debating why we have a shambles on our hands, if this legislation goes into place and is put into operation. I am confident that we will have an election in the next 12 months-I do not think we are going to depart from the constitutional processes-and that there will be a change of government. I suppose, therefore, it will fall to us to try to correct the neglect of the last six years.

SPEECH.PARA: In all of this detail that we now have before us to debate-and which will be read by the many honourable senators who have a close and very idealistic interest in the future of the Aboriginal community in Australia-one can read the story of six years of gross neglect. We have had the report of the Auditor-General before us for some time. I do not know why some of the other reports were not available earlier. Senator Tambling pointed out to me that some of these other reports are dated January and February this year. We should look at the report of the Auditor-General which was misrepresented by the Prime Minister in his statement when he suggested that the problems are mainly focused on the ADC. That is certainly not what I have found from this report. What we found in page after page was the cold bureaucratic description of the chaos which should not be described in cold and bureaucratic terms. We found the reason for that chaos. We found that on page 70 of the Auditor-General's report it says:

An examination of existing policy guidelines . . . established that the guidelines were out of date, unrealistic, not relevant, not measureable, ambiguous and too narrow. The Department was budget rather than policy driven.

Where were the Ministers when all this was happening? I will tell honourable senators where the Ministers were. Clyde Holding was out chasing national land rights, something that the bureaucracy could have advised him on the first day of the Labor Government was not achievable. The Attorney-General's Department, the Prime Minister's Department and the Department of Aboriginal Affairs could have repeated the advice that I received-that it was not a goer; it was not achievable. For 4 1/2 years the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, focused on chasing a romantic rainbow and ignored the basic administration of Aboriginal Affairs. We then got the intervention of the Prime Minister in the Northern Territory who, at Burunga, raised the proposition that we were going to have a treaty. We asked the Department of Aboriginal Affairs in the Estimates Committee shortly after that statement by the Prime Minister what work had been done by the Department on that proposal. The answer was none. It was another bit of politicking. It had nothing to do with orderly administration or the real long term interests of the Aboriginal people. One can go through page after page of this in the report. There are items under the heading `Total Breakdown of Administration'. On page 77 under the heading `Compliance with Grants Conditions', it states:
. . . considered inadequate for almost all grants examined.
In many instances financial statements received lacked lists of outstanding debtors and creditors, lists of capital items purchased, details of employment levels . . .
On page 78 it continues:

In attempting to assess program performance, audit observed that in many instances in 1987-88 there was a total absence of, or inadequate, statistics to evidence the achievement of planned measurable outcomes.

I agree that Senator Collins knows a lot about Aboriginal affairs; I wish he were the Minister. He should not come here and abuse me for the fact that when I was Minister there were higher administrative costs than there are under Labor. I am surprised there are any administrative costs under Labor. It did not administer anything. It just shovelled out the money and left the people to rot. That is this Government's record in Aboriginal affairs.

None of this has been fixed or can be fixed because morale has dropped out of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the good people are leaving or have left, and people are frightened. That is the truth about Aboriginal affairs. The silver bodgie-I cannot think of words that I am prepared to use in this place to describe the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) when I think of him prancing around the stage on this-that strutting little popinjay, will go around pretending that he is working for the good of the Aboriginal people of Australia. That is a sick joke. It is a lie. One can go through and through this document. Audit found many instances where breaches of grant conditions occurred. No remedial action was taken by the Department. There is another example on page 81:

The Project Evaluation and Funding Proposal Forms . . . did not provide adequate evidence to show the grants were made on the basis of need and that the level of funding was appropriate. Deficiencies noted included-
and so the lists go on. I do not have time to deal with them in full.

Then we get these more recently tabled reports, including those of the Public Service Commission. The Public Service Commission's report reminds me of the majority report of the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs. It is worth remembering that the whole Committee pointed out that the conditions laid down by the Minister himself for consultation with the Aboriginal community had not been met, that virtually every Aboriginal community said it had not had time to fully study and understand the report and that they expected a second round of consultation.

Then, of course, the Committee came out with a quite different conclusion-that the Bill should proceed. That is why my colleague Senator Boswell and my colleague and ex-Minister Senator Peter Baume dissented. Look at the Public Service Commission report. What a joke. I would suggest that those who want to look at the Public Service Commission report should look at pages 16, 18 and 23. Let me quote just a couple of pieces out of that report. On page 23 it says:

. . . Mr Perkins . . . in his public comments was allowed much greater licence (ranging into very delicate political issues) than is normal for a senior officer of the apolitical Australian Public Service. His robust, hands-on style perhaps accentuated these tendencies.
Those tendencies were the tendencies to have a very heavy involvement in particular staffing matters. A little later on page 23 the report goes on:

Given his volatility and style as a manager and his extraordinary range of contacts in Aboriginal communities, it is hardly remarkable that Mr Perkins was seen by a number of people as being too involved informally in some staff selection processes at various levels of his Department.

In this report Mr Perkins's network is described; his motives are not impugned. I want to say something about Mr Perkins. I worked closely with him and I regard him as a friend. He is not very pleased about the fact that I have been part of having to draw attention to deficiencies in his Department. I think Charles Perkins is an extraordinary man. He went from being an orphan child with no prospects, put himself through university by playing professional football, helped to raise the consciousness of Australians about the plight of Aboriginals in the 1960s with his freedom rides, and has had a most distinguished career of service with the Australian Public Service which has been continually sullied, if you like, by the political role he has gone on playing.

I point to the period of my own Ministry, when the head of the Department was Mr Tony Ayers, now the head of the Department of Defence, as a period which showed that, given proper ministerial guidance and support-support is perhaps the better word-Mr Perkins was able to contribute in a consistently positive way to administration. I believe that whatever faults are shown up with respect to Mr Perkins's administration are not the fault of Mr Perkins; they are the fault of his having to work under two Ministers whom I regard as having been grossly neglectful of the detail of their duties. The current Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) in particular did not give Mr Perkins the support or role which enabled him to perform in an appropriate way. If there is to be any brickbat thrown in this matter I believe it is clearly to be thrown at the political people involved and not at Mr Charles Perkins. I regret that for the last six years he has not had, in my view, appropriate political or other support from his Ministers-guidance, if you like.

This series of statements and reports will be much debated, I suspect, over the coming weeks and months. There will be many opportunities provided. I am sorry that my own contribution to the debate has had to be before I could go in full detail through all the material which has been put before us. I say again that I think this is one of the areas of Labor's greatest failure. The truth is that the next election will be won or lost on issues such as home interest rates and the Government's failure to run this splendid country in a way which enables it to produce and to maintain its place in the world. This Government will be damned because of the enormous overhang of foreign debt which puts us at enormous risk next time there is a change in the price that is paid for our products.

Those are the things that will be written large about this Government. I believe that a careful study of this Government will show that there is no area for which it should be more roundly condemned than its administration of Aboriginal affairs. So much was promised, so many votes were bought on the basis of those promises, and the performance has been third rate. The performance has been pathetic. All of this matters because there are hundreds, thousands, tens of thousands of Aboriginal people who have been led up the garden path and who are now suffering for having believed the nonsense that Labor politicians put to them. They are suffering because of the lack of orderly administration in this vital and difficult portfolio.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you have put a lot of time into exposing some of that maladministration, as have many others of our Senate colleagues. I know that the common intent of all of us has been to try to get remedies which will see positive things being done. What we have been promised today is a continuation of the worst that has been happening. We have been promised that yes, all these things have been written down by all these learned people, there are these splendid statements of intention about accountability, but the structures that are being put in place will simply compound and make more difficult the problems of the past.

I speak with very great sadness at this time. I think it is a terrible shame that we are left in the position that this Government has put us. I hope that the Australian Democrats, who will have the power to make our votes useful or not useful on this issue, will consider very carefully the reality of the position of Aboriginal Australians. If they do not, if they join with the Government in allowing this extraordinary timetable, this extraordinary proposition, to go through, then I think we are going to have a very sorry future.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION: THE WAY AHEAD

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) relating to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard, but I know honourable senators opposite will not let me do that. It is now 16 months since the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs first made a statement in the other place outlining the Government's proposals to significantly restructure the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. In that time much has happened. The Government has had the most extensive consultation ever on a piece of Commonwealth legislation affecting a particular group of people. We have had a significant response to the proposal from Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people right across the country. We have had a politically motivated smear campaign from the Opposition to try to thwart the plans of the Government and the Aboriginal community. But the Government is determined to proceed with its legislation establishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal to establish ATSIC was announced by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs on 10 December 1987. Since that time he has made many modifications, taking into account the views expressed to him and others during the extensive consultations he undertook with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. Today I will outline additional changes.
Many of these changes deal with the question of accountability. This is an area which, I remind the Senate, is just as important to Aboriginal and Islander people as it is to the Government.

During the consultations the Minister had with communities around the country on the ATSIC proposal, Aboriginal and Islander people stressed that they did not want to be set up to fail. They did not want to take part in the decision making process if it meant operating under flawed legislation. They were happy to accept the increased responsibilities but only if they received the necessary resources and training for the job. They did not want to be blamed for other people's mistakes, which has happened too often in the past. The Government has no intention of setting Aboriginal people up to fail. ATSIC will be provided with proper training and resources. But the legislation will also provide a series of checks and balances to ensure that all participants in the decision making process-from the regional councils through to Government-are accountable.
The basics of ATSIC will not be affected by any of the changes I will announce today. I remind the Senate of the main features, as contained in the Bill passed by the lower House last year:

a system of regional councils, elected by Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders resident in that region, which will determine priorities, develop regional plans, and generally represent the interests of the region;
commissioners, of whom the majority will be elected by regional councillors grouped into zones for this purpose;
the Commission replaces the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC);
programs would be administered by Commission staff with funding direct to Aboriginal organisations and individuals;

other portfolio bodies-Aboriginal Hostels Ltd (AHL) and the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS)-would retain their independent existence, but would have three ATSIC commissioners on their governing bodies;
staff would come under the Public Service Act;
the Minister's powers would balance the requirements of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management with those of accountability to the Parliament;

a new body, the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC), would be formed to provide finance and services, on an independent commercial basis, for major enterprises involving, and of benefit to, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Thus ATSIC will combine, in the one organisation, the means for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to have a real say in the management of their own affairs with an administrative structure that eliminates existing overlaps, is more responsive to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander wishes, and attains appropriate standards of accountability for public funds.
Accountability

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, has already spoken of the Government's response to the findings of the Auditor-General in his special report on the ADC and on the Department. The Government affirms its resolve to address the problem areas identified in that report with vigour and determination. We have examined the Auditor-General's findings to see where they may bear upon the ATSIC legislation, and in particular on the provisions relating to accountability. At the same time we have taken into account the report of the Department of Finance into the ADC's financial administration. Both these reports lend support to the view that our proposals for ATSIC will result in a more effective administration of Aboriginal Affairs. It is already the case that the ATSIC Bill contains stronger provisions than the ADC Act-for example, through the authority of the Minister to approve the Estimates, which he lacks under the ADC Act.

Changes to the Bill must be considered in the context of the basic principle of ATSIC that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should have greater control over matters affecting them. The question is one of balancing this principle with the principle of ministerial accountability for the correct and efficient use of public funds. We therefore propose that the ATSIC Bill be amended to:

establish within ATSIC an Office of Evaluation and Audit, to undertake evaluations and internal audits on programs, projects and procedures. Project evaluations will be on a continuing basis, while for programs and regions there will be a three-year cycle of general audits. More intensive examination will of course flow from any shortcomings revealed in the general audits. The Office will report regularly to the Commission and the Minister, and annually to the Parliament through the ATSIC annual reports. The Head of the Office will have senior rank, and will be appointed by the Minister;
require ATSIC to observe financial directions to be made by the Minister;
require ATSIC to keep the Minister informed about specific projects that are encountering difficulties;
require ATSIC to prepare a corporate plan and to consult the Minister about it; and
clarify the distinction between commercial and non-commercial activities-a problem which has bedevilled the ADC.

It might be noted that one of the recurring criticisms by the Auditor-General was that projects were funded without there being community plans against which to assess priorities. The ATSIC Bill addresses this need. Coordination of community and regional planning is one of the functions of regional councils.
Senate Select Committee

The Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs reported on 28 February on the ATSIC Bill. I have tabled the Government's responses to the recommendations of that Committee. We have accepted, in whole or in substance, the great bulk of the recommendations of the majority report. Those recommendations include, I point out, support for the Bill proceeding in the Senate.

I shall confine my comments here to the more substantial proposals for change to the Bill, commencing with those relating to the regional councils and the election of commissioners. The Select Committee expressed some concerns about the disparities in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations as between regions in a zone, and as between zones. These differences exist because we have sought, as a result of the extensive consultations which have been held, to accommodate the wishes of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as to where boundaries should be drawn, thus taking into account kinship ties and community of interest. This has undoubtedly been the right approach. Comparisons with legislatures and the principle of one vote one value miss the point; ATSIC is not a parliament.

Nonetheless the Government recognises that a system where one region in a zone with a small population has the same voting strength in elections for a commissioner as a much larger region has some inequitable features. Accordingly we accept the Select Committee majority's recommendation 11 to provide a sliding scale of regional councillors, starting with 10 for regions with populations of under 1,000, with an additional councillor for each additional 1,000 or part thereof up to a maximum of 20-the number presently in the Bill.

We have also addressed the issue, identified by the Select Committee but on which it made no formal recommendation, of substantial population imbalances as between zones. To this end we propose that the five most populous zones be split in two, thus raising the number of elected commissioners to 17. In New South Wales, the Sydney region will comprise a new zone, as will the Perth region in Western Australia. The Northern Territory zone, which comprises much of the Northern Territory, will be split into two separate zones.

In Queensland, which has the largest Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population, two new zones will be created. One is for the Brisbane region, and the other to accommodate the wishes of people living in the so-called DOGIT communities-those who hold a form of title to their land under deeds of grant in trust-to be encompassed within the same zone. A new map is being drawn up to show the proposed changes. We believe these proposals will make for a better balanced system of regional councils and, through the revised zone structure, a more equitable system for the election of commissioners.

Recommendation 12 proposes, inter alia, voluntary enrolment for regional council elections, but compulsory voting for those who do enrol. The Government's intention has been that no special roll be established and that, as with the elections for the former National Aboriginal Conference, voters fill out a `voter card' on the day. There would be mechanisms for testing the eligibility of voters to take part in the election.

The Government appreciates that the Select Committee has been concerned to find a system which would provide both the opportunity for persons of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent to choose whether they wished to vote in regional council elections and a means for checking the eligibility of voters. The Government has given careful thought to voting systems. In its view the overriding consideration is that a public roll based on race, whatever its purpose, should not be established in this country. We will explore possible alternative systems with the Australian Electoral Commission. The details will be contained in the electoral rules which I am to prescribe in accordance with clause 95 of the Bill. That clause provides that the Parliament may disallow such rules.

A number of the recommendations are for tightening up existing provisions of the Bill. They deal with such matters as eligibility for elected or appointed office, pecuniary interests, full written assessments of proposals before substantial expenditures are approved, acting appointments, and employment of consultants. The Government accepts these recommendations, with some modifications to bring them in line with the requirements of other organisations established by statute. Although it modifies the Government's original intention to bring all bodies in my portfolio under one umbrella, we will also accept recommendation 3, which proposes that the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies should continue to be established under its own legislation. Other aspects of the proposed reforms to the Institute's structure will proceed.

The Select Committee looked closely at the preamble to the Bill. The majority, while recognising that concerns about possible wider ramifications of the preamble were not well based, has suggested that it could help to allay such concerns if the preamble were removed from the Bill and moved separately, without amendment, as a resolution of both Houses. The Government stands by its conviction that the preamble is of such significance that it should not be separated from the Bill. Australians should not back away from acknowledging, in a symbolically important way, the facts of history and our resolve to address the present effects of past injustice. We will not be diverted in our purpose by those who have chosen to represent the preamble as having a degree of legal force that it does not possess.

The Select Committee's recommendation 2 is important, and has received close attention. It proposes that enterprise and related functions of the ADC be transferred, not to ATSIC as the Bill proposes, but to the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation-the AEDC. ADC's housing functions, however, would transfer as planned to ATSIC.

The Government has decided not to transfer those functions to the AEDC. The reason for this is that the AEDC is intended to operate in quite a different way. It will not administer programs but will facilitate and participate in significant commercial enterprises involving, and of benefit to, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It would be inappropriate, and would dilute the commercial nature of the AEDC, to have it take on programs, especially programs which include quasi-commercial aspects such as grants and concessional loans. ATSIC, through the regional council planning processes is designed to accommodate a whole range of community needs and in so doing will reduce the present wasteful duplication of administrative structures, including field services. I note here that the recent report of the Auditor-General has highlighted the problem that the ADC has often faced in separating its commercial and social functions. Maintaining the AEDC as a strictly commercial body will help address those concerns expressed by the Auditor-General. The ATSIC Bill will improve the capacity of the Minister to oversee enterprise activities in line with recommendations made by the Auditor-General.

With regard to the first recommendation of the Senate Select Committee that a separate Office of Aboriginal Affairs be retained within the Employment, Education and Training portfolio, I should point out that the ATSIC Bill does not restrict the advice available to the Minister to that provided by ATSIC. Indeed, it was always envisaged, under the ATSIC proposal, that there could be circumstances where the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and also the portfolio Minister, might occasionally require separate departmental advice on issues concerning ATSIC, and that this advice would come from the portfolio Department.

It will be clear from what I have said that the Government rejects the minority report of Opposition senators in seeking to have the Bill withdrawn. They have not established a case. Their report is long on assertion and colourful phrase, but woefully short on accuracy and fact. For reasons best known to themselves they wish to perpetuate a system-a system which they created-which is patently not working as it should. It is not a system for meeting the legitimate expectations of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people for a real say in their own affairs.
Other Changes

The opportunity will also be taken to make a number of other changes, essentially machinery and minor in nature, to the legislation-for example, in relation to dates of operation. A summary of the main changes to the ATSIC legislation is attached to the printed copies of this statement.
Implementation and Timing

ATSIC has already been delayed well beyond the original proposed starting date. That has created considerable problems for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who naturally wish to know that promised and needed reforms will not be put off again. The delays have also left portfolio staff uncertain about their futures. In addition they have had to deal with a constant barrage of abuse from the Opposition as well as cope with the onerous task of responding to hundreds of questions on notice which have taken them away from their normal duties. We are very conscious of the additional difficulties this has caused for them, as it has for portfolio management. As the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in this place I take this opportunity to express my gratitude for the way in which portfolio staff have continued to undertake their demanding and important tasks with commitment and efficiency, in often trying circumstances.

There are still some reports to be completed, including a further report by the Auditor-General and some investigations by Mr Andrew Menzies. It is unlikely that these reports will show a need for further legislative change, but should it prove to be otherwise the Minister shall, of course, bring forward proposals for such change. The timetable that we propose for implementing ATSIC takes this into account. I would also add that we will continue our consultations with the staff associations in the lead up to the implementation of our proposals.

The amendments I have outlined are important but do not affect the substance of ATSIC. We believe they will be widely welcomed and acceptable as desirable improvements. We therefore propose to press ahead with the legislation in the present sittings of the Parliament. Once the legislation is passed, there are a number of processes to be completed before the new Commission can become fully operational. These include the holding of regional council elections, the processes for which will take some months, and the election by regional councillors of the Commissioners.

The Government is very conscious of the need to minimise uncertainty and avoid further drift. It is also very conscious of the degree of confusion which has been generated in the community as a result of the political campaign waged by the Opposition. At the same time we recognise that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people need time to understand the changes that are being made and, more broadly, to get to know more about ATSIC and how it will work. They need to have this information before being asked to make the important decisions of electing their regional councillors and then those regional councillors electing Commissioners.

Our preferred course is that the Commission be established on an interim basis from 1 October 1989. This will be done under transitional arrangements which will allow for the appointment by the Minister of five Commissioners, including the Chairperson. This arrangement will have a 12 months sunset clause. We would then allow an extensive period for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to become familiar with the way ATSIC will work and for the administrative structure to shake down. A major educative and training effort will be made during this time. Regional councillor elections will then be held, and ATSIC would become fully operational, within this 12 month period. This phasing-in approach will help ensure that ATSIC comes into operation smoothly and effectively.

Already the ATSIC concept has been open for consultation and comment for over 15 months. We have made a series of refinements and modifications as a result of those processes. We will also ensure that ATSIC is properly resourced to undertake its important tasks. In its management and administration, ATSIC must have its priorities right from the start. It will have to put a lot of effort into such areas as corporate planning, program budgeting, policy and program guidelines, and evaluation and internal audit.

Another vital need to come out of the inquiries is for a much improved training effort, to enhance the skills of those working within Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and of portfolio staff and to ensure that ATSIC is properly understood by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Some State and Territory governments have expressed concerns about ATSIC. The Minister has sought on a number of occasions to provide opportunities to meet with them and is continuing to do so. This is notwithstanding the fact that no State or Territory should have anything to fear from ATSIC. It appears, however, that some are happier to complain rather than put their views to the test.
Immediate Needs

ATSIC will not be operational for some months, but there is clearly a need, identified in the reports of the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General, to act now to remedy deficiencies within the present structures. We shall ensure that the ADC, during its remaining life, operates on a similar basis to ATSIC and in a manner that properly reflects Government priorities. The problem lies, at least in part, with defects in the ADC Act. By a combination of amendments to the Act, cognately with the ATSIC legislation, and of directions to the ADC under section 11 (1) of that Act, we will require Ministerial approval of estimates and consultation of its corporate plan; issue broad policy guidelines, especially relating to financial administration; and empower the Minister to request information and advice. A summary of the main proposals is also attached to this statement.

As far as the Department of Aboriginal Affairs is concerned, problems identified in the reports can only be addressed by administrative action. This action is currently being taken. In this regard I am able to report that considerable progress has been made in respect of a number of matters identified by the Auditor-General as requiring improvements. These include substantive work on the development of revised performance indicators; the acquittal of grants to Aboriginal organisations; revision of financial guidelines for grants; and the acquisition of additional field resources for some Regional Offices of the Department.
Conclusion
The changes we have made to ATSIC have not come about as a result of actions by the Opposition. It has had the opportunity but has failed to make any constructive contribution.

The Opposition has only sought to delay the proposal and generate confusion within Aboriginal and Islander communities. It has demonstrated that it is not interested in any kind of progressive reform. It is certainly not interested in Aboriginal people being part of the decision making process.

This is the only conclusion we can draw from the Opposition's stance. It cannot accept that Aboriginal people must be part of the processes of government. It cannot accept that Aboriginal people are the ones who can best determine their own needs and priorities. I am happy to say that its efforts have clearly failed.

Now, for the first time, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians will have a real say in matters affecting them. We are putting an end at last to paternalism, to the idea that others must decide what is best. We cannot amend history, but we can act to correct its adverse effects for today's and tomorrow's Australians. That is what ATSIC is all about. It is an achievement of which all Australians will be proud.

Leave granted.

4. The numbers of regional councillors in a Region will vary according to population, starting at 10 for populations of under 1,000 and rising to 20 where populations exceed 10,000. Special arrangements will apply in respect of the Torres Strait Region.
