6. There will be a number of amendments designed to improve accountability. These will include requirements for the Commission to-
- prepare a corporate plan and consult the Minister about it
- keep the Minister informed about programs and projects encountering difficulties
- maintain a clear distinction between funding for commercially viable and non-commercial enterprises
- observe financial directions to be made by the Minister
- have before it a full written assessment of proposals before approving substantial expenditures.

7. The criterion for ineligibility for candidacy for office will be the same as applies to candidates for ACT self-government ie. under sentence for an offence carrying a maximum penalty of 5 years or longer.

8. Clause 3 of the Bill will be amended to include specific reference to self-management for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as an object of the Bill, and to include relevant aspects of section 3 of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.
ATTACHMENT B
SUMMARY OF THE MAIN CHANGES
AFFECTING THE ABORIGINAL
DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
1. Ministerial approval will be required for the ADC's estimates, and for any significant variation to them.
2. The Minister will be able to request information and advice.
3. The distinction between commercially viable and non-commercial enterprises will be clarified.
4. Financial guidelines will be issued.
5. Staff will be employed under the Public Service Act.
6. Regular reports will be required to the Minister on such matters as finance, current status of projects (including significant lapses or breaches of terms and conditions), and use of delegations.
NOTE : These changes will be effected by a combination of legislative amendment and ministerial directions under section 11 (1) of the Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

The report that we are considering is entitled ATSIC: The Way Ahead. Let me repeat that-ATSIC: The Way Ahead. What an ironic title to give such a paper. This paper presented today in conjunction with another statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on issues related to the administration of Aboriginal Affairs and the paper presented by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, in response to recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs are a fraud. They are a fraud not only to all Australians but to the 200,000 Aboriginal Australians.

I believe that the importance of this issue cannot be stressed too strongly. In fact, I believe that the most disappointed senators today, in considering the various reports that have now been made, must be Senator McMullan, Senator Collins and Senator Coulter. They spent a great deal of time as members of the Senate Select Committee inquiring into Aboriginal Affairs. They hassled for months with the particular issues and with a very important and dramatic report to the Senate. We have seen them insulted by the tactics of the Labor Party today. I remind the Senate that Senator Boswell and Senator Peter Baume put in a minority report that highlighted many of the issues of many of the problems.

In looking at this issue today we must consider the way in which it has been presented. In fact, it is an information overload which has serious connotations. It must mean that every senator-in fact, anybody who is seriously considering this issue-must ask: what is the Government hiding? Today, as Senator Chaney said earlier, three very important ministerial statements have been made. At the same time, we have had put on our desks a report of the Public Service Commissioner, two reports of the Department of Finance, a report from Mr Menzies and, of course, in recent weeks and months we have also had the special report of the Auditor-General and the report to which I have referred, the Senate Select Committee report on the whole issue of Aboriginal affairs. Each and every one of those reports and ministerial statements demand a comprehensive consideration by the Parliament. It is very interesting to trace the dates of those various reports and see when they were handed down. I ask the very important question: why were the Department of Finance reports not tabled concurrently with the special report of the Auditor-General which was tabled here several weeks ago? Why was it held back? The dates invite comparison and make one very suspicious of the motives.

Today's statements by Ministers need very special consideration. Senator Tate gave a response to the report of the Senate Select Committee. It addressed all of the 40 recommendations of the majority report, all of the recommendations of the minority report and the various recommendations of Senator Coulter. In a very cavalier manner, the Government has decided to push ahead and press on with a very different agenda. In fact, it takes one back to the adjectival way of doing things that Mr Hand seems to have in the administration of his portfolio.

Let me remind honourable senators that in December 1987, as Senator Tate said in his statement, some 16 months ago, there was an attempt to bring forward the first serious consideration of the new administration of this area. That document was called Foundations for the Future. In March and April 1988, mark 2 and mark 3 were presented to the Parliament with various amendments, changes, modifications and ratifications. What did we get today? We had further statements such as this: `In light of whatever, we may have to amend this again further down the track'. What an insult to all of the people who gave submissions so generously to that Senate Select Committee. What about the people throughout Australia in the Department-the public servants, the members of the Aboriginal Development Commission and also the staff of the ADC-who have been seeking for much longer than 16 months to get it right?

The Prime Minister made a very pious statement in the Parliament today. It is almost a papal encyclical. If one looks at the commitments, background and history, one finds very little in what the Prime Minister put down. Let me highlight the major issues that he raised, and he raised only two. He said that there were two imperatives for government. He continued:
the first imperative for self-management, by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, of Government programs designed to assist their well being.

Second, there is the thoroughly complementary imperative for proper ministerial responsibility and accountability for, and effective parliamentary scrutiny of, programs as a whole, especially in relation to their financial administration.

The Labor Government has failed on both of those counts. It has now made a mockery of self-management in the whole process that it has adopted in seeking to get into place a new form of Aboriginal administration. In regard to ministerial responsibility and accountability, what have we been asking for in the Senate, in Senate Estimates committees and in the Senate Select Committee for the last 16 months if it has not been the rotten, lousy ministerial responsibility and accountability of Minister Hand, who has walked away from those very essential tenets?

The Prime Minister in his statement acknowledges that there are major problems in this portfolio. He said that there are shortcomings; some serious ones are evident; that there are areas where there was a lower than acceptable standard of administration. He said that the staff classifications were not well founded in terms of classification principles and processes. He sought to take the mickey out of the Public Service Commissioner in his report and to play down the very important issues that arise. I will address that aspect a little later. The Prime Minister's statement certainly acknowledges the problems, but it does not go anywhere near giving a commitment to addressing them. If one looks carefully at the final paragraph of what the Prime Minister said, one will see that it is nothing but sheer hypocrisy. He said:

The Government's approach is, as I have indicated, to draw upon the lessons from the inquiries and look to the future to ensure that mechanisms are put in place and support provided so that future administration is on a sound footing. We are determined to address administrative problems in a way which ensures a higher quality of future administration in this very important area of government and, in the long run, a higher quality of life and sense of belonging for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

That statement should be compared with the results and with the action of Minister Hand. Of course, the Prime Minister, Mr Hand and Mr Snowdon constantly scream that the Opposition is supposedly engaged in a campaign of smear and of attacking people's credibility. A stream of allegations dogs the area. I ask them to name the smears, to name the people. It is fine just to say it. We have addressed hundreds of areas of financial mismanagement. Sure, a couple of people were hurt along the way, but they were all associated with the problems. There is no smearing of Aboriginal people in the community. Mr Acting Deputy President, let me assure you that in the electorate that I represent 25 per cent of my constituents are traditional Aboriginals. There are 35,000 such people in my electorate. I think I know very well the way that they feel on this issue.

What the Government is seeking to do today is to lump all of the sins together. Let me remind the Senate that the problems did not occur on the scale that we have uncovered in the last year-looking back over the period of the Labor administration of five years-under the previous administration of the Liberal-National Party Government. The Prime Minister's statement is a mockery when it comes to self-management for Aboriginal people. It walks away from genuine ministerial responsibility and accountability.

I also remind the Senate very clearly that what we are talking about in the establishment of a new Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is something that will represent, or purport to represent, 200,000 people around Australia. It will have a budget well in excess of $600m, probably closer to $1 billion per annum. We need to balance this against all the problems that are associated with the Aboriginal Development Commission, which is an existing statutory authority with an existing budget of $30m. That is $600m compared with $30m. The balance is currently administered by the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and other government agencies. Maybe it is time that taxpayers, Australians, ran for the bunkers on this issue. The concerns we are expressing are extreme and very genuine. As I have said, Minister Hand's document is entitled The Way Ahead. It is based on the Foundations for the Future document of some 16 months ago. But those documents are certainly not the way ahead and they are certainly creating a great deal of controversy in the broad community and in the Aboriginal community.

The legislation to put the ATSIC proposal in place has to come back before the Senate. We need to note that the Bill is underpinned by the idea that the Aboriginal people are entitled to special administrative and representative arrangements because they have a special claim. The argument has overtones of compensation and of Aborigines being a superior class of Australian citizen. I refer to a couple of the many lines beginning `And whereas' in the preamble to the Bill, especially written in with special significance:
AND WHEREAS they were dispossessed by subsequent European occupation and have no recognised rights over land yet recognised by the Courts other than those granted or recognised by the Crown;
AND WHEREAS that dispossession occurred without compensation and no serious attempt was made to reach a lasting and equitable agreement with them on the use of their land;

On it goes-`and whereas', `and whereas', `and whereas'. The Minister has the audacity to argue that this preamble will not be influential in the courts in future. What sheer and absolute rubbish. In contrast, the coalition asserts that while the Aboriginal community in Australia has a special status, as first Australians, their rights and responsibilities are no different from those of other Australians. As Australians they are entitled to government assistance to meet their basic needs, and as the most disadvantaged cultural group it is appropriate that special mechanisms be employed to improve living standards. The Government philosophy leads to giving Aborigines control of a statutory authority overseeing their interests within the nation. The coalition philosophy leads to a bureaucracy which remains accountable to the Parliament but which employs distinctive consultative mechanisms to ensure that Aboriginal advancement programs are appropriate and effective at all levels. The coalition clearly rejects Aboriginal self-determination as represented by ATSIC in favour of very real self-management and economic self-sufficiency. We need to be very careful in that.

I turn to the document The Way Ahead. We always have to look for the hidden agenda in anything Mr Hand writes. The hidden agenda for this one is tucked away, down towards the back. As I said, this makes a sheer mockery of self-management for Aboriginal people. On page 19 of the draft I have it is stated:

Our preferred course is that the Commission be established on an interim basis from 1 October 1989. This will be done under transitional arrangements which will allow for the appointment by the Minister of five Commissioners, including the Chairperson. This arrangement will have a 12 months sunset clause.
We would then allow for an extensive period for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to become familiar with the way ATSIC will work, and for the administrative structure to shake down.

Come on! Again Mr Hand is going behind the intent of the Parliament. He is going behind legislation. How much do I have to remind people of what Mr Hand did last May when he chucked out a group of commissioners on the Aboriginal Development Commission who happened to be putting an alternative view? They were all eminent Aboriginal people in the area of administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —He still has not apologised to them, either.

—He has not apologised; he has not looked at their position in any way. What is he doing now? He is bringing back another hand-picked-pardon the pun-group of representatives to run a $600m budget. He is completely bypassing the Department of Aboriginal Affairs bureaucracy; he is gobbling up the Aboriginal Development Commission and any other area that he can possibly get his hands on. That is the sort of hidden agenda we find tucked into the back pages of a report like this, supposedly based on consultation with Aboriginal people throughout Australia. That provision will be horrific for Aboriginal people throughout Australia. The old ADC board had a significant number of people on it, from different groups. Even the proposals in the Act for regions, zones and everything else enabled some degree of participation in that process of administrative review. But, no, we will now have a hand-picked, five-member, special 12-month sunset clause condition interposed. I hope the Australian Democrats will not buy that. That would be against every principle that I accept that the Democrats stand for in trying to get benefits for Aboriginal people throughout Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: So much for this most extensive consultation ever that Mr Hand claims. He tries to hide behind criticism by saying that it is smear. Like heck! In no way is that the case. He goes back to his Foundations for the Future document of 1987, which was so fundamentally flawed, and says that the Government has made many modifications and of course will make many more all the way along the line. The legislation is flawed and the people who have to bear the blame for this mistake this time are surely the Labor Cabinet and the Labor Caucus. They must have rolled Senator McMullan and Senator Collins, who must be squirming as a result of this document and the weight of evidence that was presented to their very effective committee. Areas of change are reflected all the way through, whether it be zones and regions, the Institute of Aboriginal Studies or the different groups and how the Minister is going to achieve accountability and effectiveness between them all.
Let me come to a few more curly ones that the Minister wants to tuck into the legislation, without consultation with Aboriginal people. I remind the Senate of this intention in his statement:
establish within ATSIC an Office of Evaluation and Audit . . . The Office will report regularly to the Commission and the Minister, and annually to the Parliament through the ATSIC Annual Reports.

So the Minister has put a special audit bureau into ATSIC, underneath the top of the pyramid. It is little wonder when we read the special Auditor-General's report tabled a few weeks ago. When the Auditor-General reviewed this entire portfolio, as a result of the work of Senate estimates committees last year, he found:

Budgetary planning was not based on relevant quantified target objectives against which performance could be/was measured . . . general control of DAA expenditure was unsatisfactory; funding for community development was generally provided in the absence of plans for such development, without planned targets and without measuring the success of outcomes in terms of achieving planned community development; Department was unable to confirm that funds it provided for 1,752 projects had been expended on the purposes for which it had been provided. The total unacquitted grants could exceed $100m but was not known, though 783 of the projects did involve allocations of $67,749,576.

TALK.START.PARA: —They went chasing Mr Friedrich around the country for some $23m.

—It is certainly worth noting the comparison. Now an Office of Evaluation and Audit is to be put inside ATSIC to do this type of reporting. The Auditor-General's report has not been fully and comprehensively debated anywhere in this Parliament because the Australian Labor Party does not have the courage to put it on the agenda for the House of Representatives or bring it back where it properly should be discussed-in this place. We talk about the changing of the guard by way of a number of regions and zones and the population balances and the electoral colleges. Mr Hand has sought to break every Labor principle in the book. —Read what the Senate committee said.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to keep coming back to so many areas. But let us look at the Public Service Commissioner's report. Morale is at an abysmal level, and members despair of ever being able to do their jobs properly. They have inadequate resources, especially of staff, to deliver services and programs to the clients of the portfolio. Members of the Public Service have been under a lot of pressure for the last six months because there have been problems, and even the Prime Minister has acknowledged that in his statement. But what support have they received from the Minister, Mr Hand? They have received none. He has constantly undermined their system. He has gone behind them. He has dealt with the pseudo Public Service of the land councils, the radical organisations in the national coalition and all of the other organisations. Of course, he is now seeking to bypass the whole lot of them to put into place a special, new, hand-picked commission, not one that is accountable to the Aboriginal constituencies to carry out an administrative reform, not one that is accountable to this Parliament in the ways in which it should be.

What about Minister Hand's commitment to the State and Northern Territory governments for further consultation on this matter? There is no reflection whatsoever in today's statement that he is going to do anything in that regard. Yet, the public announcements and everything else have been, `Yes, we are going to take account of what industry, commerce, State governments and Aboriginal groups want around Australia'. My own commitments-

Parliamentary and other, will prevent me from attending such a meeting until the last week of April. Perhaps we would have seen a different view and attitude if commonsense had properly prevailed.

It is clear that the Aboriginal Development Commission is again to be fiddled with in the interim. It is good that we will have the opportunity on Thursday and Friday of this week to deal with these matters when the Senate Estimates committees are back on deck. What flowed from those questions-all of these reports, inquiries and everything else that Minister Hand and Mr Hawke are now attempting to sweep under the carpet? But at least this week we will be able to ask questions on notice and take up these very important issues that have to be addressed.

The Aboriginal people are being affected. We need to remember that we have a Minister who is prepared to bypass totally every system and every principle that I thought the Australian Labor Party stood for in the Parliament. Not one member of Hand's left wing faction in the Senate has got up and debated this matter. On one occasion Senator Bolkus got up, stuffed up a question and then retreated into his tortoiseshell. Ever since then, not even one member of Hand's left wing faction has attempted to bail him out. This has been left to credible senators like Senator McMullan and Senator Collins. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was elected to the Senate I came into this place with a considerable respect for the processes of representative democracy and the procedures which I hoped I would observe in this place. I find that today, in dealing with this matter, those processes for which I had such a high regard have been quite seriously abused. I note that on Wednesday evening the Treasurer, Mr Keating, is to make a major statement. Thursday's newspapers will be full of that matter. This afternoon we are dealing with three-I emphasise `three'-ministerial statements which are ill-prepared and which are intertwined in such a way that it is difficult to work out exactly what is going on. In the short time available it is impossible to look at them closely, but I have discovered one major inconsistency between them. This very important matter, as previous speakers have pointed out, has been before the Senate in very detailed ways. It has been before a number of committees of inquiry and before other inquiries over a long period-since December 1987. For the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) to push this matter through on this day in this way can only be described in fairly crude terms as `a snow job'. It is an attempt to push through a very important piece of legislation which is before the Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and before the public so that it does not get proper consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the statement which was made by Senator Button on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on the administration of Aboriginal Affairs. In the statement the Prime Minister in quoting Senator Bonner stated:
He was able to say that because the weight of the responses to the original Bill-
he is speaking of the original Aboriginal Development Commission Bill-
was to reduce the role of the Minister and expand the role of the Commission.
Further on there is another quotation:
In reaffirming my Government's support for ATSIC, I make the point that, given this legislative history,-
and this is the important point-
the proposed new Commission is the logical and appropriate next step for the advancement of both the great principles of self-management and ministerial accountability.
Yet, as Senator Tambling and others have pointed out, one comes to the second point of the Summary of the Principal Changes Proposed to the ATSIC Legislation and finds:
For an initial period of up to 12 months, the Commission will operate on an interim basis with 5 Commissioners appointed by the Minister.

That is a serious conflict of meaning between the words in the Prime Minister's statement when, again, he is reflecting-and I think quite rightly-on the need to set up a structure which properly reflects the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people in terms of self-determination and self-management. Here one finds that everything the Minister is saying and everything that the Senate Select Committee has been working towards is denied by that simple action proposed by the Minister to set up the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) as a commission of five appointed commissioners.

The wealth of information which has been presented to us today is also worth stressing, as Senator Tambling has done. Not only do we have three ministerial statements, but also we have the four other statements, some of which clearly the Government has had for a considerable period and which would have been very useful to have as preparation for this debate this afternoon. The Prime Minister's statement says, amongst other things, that we should be learning from the past. As I have indicated on several previous occasions, I felt that my function in the Senate Select Committee was to look closely at the material which was coming out of the various other inquiries into the administration of Aboriginal affairs-both the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC)-to learn from those things, and to attempt to set up as far as possible, an administrative structure for Aboriginal affairs which would function better in the future. We need to bear in mind, along with that general principle, that the two basic principles on which the Prime Minister reflects and which need to be balanced are first, the principle, of self-management, self-determination, and, second, the broad principle that one needs a structure which is accountable. These difficult to reconcile functions need to be built into this better structure.

I cannot help but reflect on the way in which the Aboriginal Development Commission was grossly distorted in May last year when the Minister, Mr Hand, saw fit to remove certain commissioners who had objected to the proposal for ATSIC as it was at that stage. An alternative proposal was put before both the Minister and subsequently the Committee which, interestingly, in one respect, the Committee was minded to take up and incorporate in its recommendation No. 2; that the economic development type functions should be properly put with the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation-the new body-which will administer the capital fund and have responsibility for the investment of that capital fund. That should be separated from the social welfare type functions which would be properly administered by ATSIC.

Given that the Minister has shown himself incapable of making appropriate appointments to the ADC-and I point out that some 80 per cent of the problems of the ADC which required investigation were problems which became evident after that ministerial rearrangement-I cannot support, and the Democrats will not be supporting, this interim arrangement to set up a commission of five commissioners appointed by the Minister. If we are to learn from the past, let us look at the past, at the history of this Minister in relation to the sorts of appointments he has made and the sort of mess they have got the ADC into. If one looks at that and learns from the past-the Prime Minister's own words-one learns that that system will simply not work. It will be a worse situation. It certainly will not address the hollow, repeated claim by the Minister that he is working towards self-determination and self-management.

I cannot help reflecting also on the fact that the Minister is also calling in one of his other statements for a corporate plan for this new body. Interestingly, after a rather shaky beginning, in which the ADC had some difficulties which were investigated by a House of Representatives committee which reported in 1985 and 1986 and after the appointment of Mrs Shirley McPherson to head the ADC, it seems to me that during her brief administration, before Minister Hand intervened, the ADC was sorting itself out, and one of the things it was getting was a corporate plan. In fact, it was doing precisely what the Minister is now recommending ATSIC should do. It seems a cruel irony that the Minister is now turning around and attempting to claim that only in his integrated structure will the development of corporate plans and proper administration be achieved when in fact he has destroyed the one part of the administration of Aboriginal affairs which seems to me to be largely on the road to sorting itself out and developing a sound management practice. Again, I merely reflect on the Minister's and the Prime Minister's words that we should look at history. In looking at history we find that this Minister is certainly not a Minister to be trusted with the appointment of people to take up these new functions as he is proposing in point 2 of attachment A to the statement of the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate).

In responding to the particular recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, recommendation 12 is that a roll be established as a prerequirement for the conduct of elections. Recommendation 12 says:

This population should be, in each instance, the population of people on an electoral roll. While placing one's name on the electoral roll should be voluntary, voting should be compulsory thereafter for those whose names are on the roll. The recall provisions should be exercisable only by those on the electoral role.

This recommendation was seriously considered by the Committee as one which would expedite the functioning of ATSIC. It would make it quite clear who was eligible to vote and would also remove from the time of the election any challenges to eligibility to vote, so that when the elections were held the votes could be counted fairly quickly. Interestingly, in making a response to this the Minister says: the possibility is being explored within the Australian Electoral Commission of a confidential system which would allow for the use of existing Federal electoral rolls combined with an acceptable mechanism for checking the bona fides of voters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Electoral Commissioner hasn't any electoral rolls at the moment; one cannot get a copy from his office.

—Leaving aside the mechanism by which this might be done, to which Senator Stone is referring, the Minister is saying there that he is investigating the establishment of an electoral roll. Yet at page 11 we find that recommendation 12 proposes, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: voluntary enrolment for Regional Council elections, but compulsory voting for those who do enrol. The Government's intention has been that no special roll be established and that, as with the elections for the . . .

So even after this delay, and given the chicanery of the Government in attempting to push these three documents through at such short notice, together with the various accompanying government reports, we find that the Government has internal conflicts in the various statements it is making. On the one hand it it saying that the recommendation of the Senate Select Committee that a roll be established is being investigated by the Electoral Commission, and, on the other hand, it is saying in the other statement that it has already rejected that recommendation.

In relation to the preamble-I find the right document. This confusion just indicates the degree to which the Government has attempted to obfuscate this whole matter. As Senator Tambling has indicated, the preamble to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1988 contains the word `Whereas' a number of times. According to the Government, that preamble has no impact in law whatsoever. A number of people drew the Committee's attention to their concern that the word `Whereas' may have some relevance in law. The Committee for two reasons-and I stress `for two reasons'-recommended that the preamble be separated from the legislation and passed in a cognate debate, or at least be debated, as a separate motion of the Senate.

The two reasons were: firstly, if the Government is saying that the word has no force in law, then it is appropriate to make quite certain that it has no force in law, by separating the preamble from the rest of the Bill. That reason is addressed by the Minister. But the second reason which the Minister totally fails to address, is that a number of Aboriginal people have been led to believe that that preamble does have some force in law. In other words, I believe they have been dishonestly dealt with by this Government by the inclusion of that preamble, and it is simply a matter of honesty that that preamble be separated so that it is absolutely clear that, if it has no force in law, it becomes a motion of the Senate, it is put through as a motion of the Senate, and it has exactly the same force as far as Aboriginal people are concerned. Nobody, and most importantly no Aboriginal people, must be misled into thinking they have got more out of this Government than they have, because the Government, by its own admission, is clearly not offering anything by putting that preamble in the front of the Bill.

I am extremely disappointed-I cannot stress it more strongly-with the way in which this Government has chosen to deal with this whole package of material which it has brought in on this day on which we have to deal with other important matters. It is delaying the release of important documents which are relevant to our consideration, while appearing to satisfy a number of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee. If we look through the list in one of these documents, it appears that all but about four of the recommendations have been accepted. In the response, that particular recommendation regarding the five commissioners to take over the functions of ATSIC is not mentioned. We have to find another document before it is revealed that its structure, for 18 months into the future, would not be according to the model anyway. The whole process has been one of deceit and has been misleading.

I came into this place with a certain amount of respect for Mr Hand. I have found it very difficult to maintain that respect as this process has gone down the path of various ministerial statements and attacks on Senate committees and the like over the time that we have had to deal with this Minister. I can only assume that he is less concerned about the real welfare of Aboriginal people than he is about winning, in a very crude political sense. He has invented something which he calls ATSIC, and now he is simply intent on getting something called ATSIC up, and being able to wave that fact before everybody and to say, `Look, I have won'. We are not about winning in this place, particularly when it comes to Aboriginal welfare; we are about a very serious matter, the improvement in the lot of Aboriginal people.

I am still committed to the ideal of self-determination and self-management. I am still committed to the ideal that the original ATSIC proposal purports to address, but I am not convinced that this Minister is at all serious about addressing that matter and at the same time ensuring that there is proper accountability in the structure which he is now putting before us.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Corporal Punishment in New South Wales Schools

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn, to enable Estimates Committees to meet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I intend to take just a few minutes of the Senate's time to outline that yesterday was a black day for education, if not in Australia, then at least in the State of New South Wales. It was a day when the clocks were turned back, when the repression of years past again raised its ugly head, a day when supposed community leaders decided it was correct to use violence against the young people in their charge. All of this was done in the name of education. Yesterday must mark one of the low points of educational leadership in New South Wales. To bring back the cane is a step which indicates the educational administration has lost control and forgotten what education is all about.

SPEECH.PARA: The word `education' is derived from the Latin `ducere' meaning `to lead', and is prefixed by `ex', which means `out of'. The word `education', therefore, is most apt. As a civilised nation it is appropriate that we be led out-led out from ignorance, from bigotry, from hatred and from oppression-towards knowledge and understanding. Instead of concentrating on education, instead of adopting measures to assist teachers to help students who have behaviour problems, instead of employing specialists who can provide that assistance, the education system in New South Wales has joined repressive societies in resorting to the use of violence.

We now have a situation in New South Wales where those who have been incarcerated for crimes against society have far more rights than a child at school. Prisoners are no longer flogged. Prisoners have been accused by one section of society, tried by another and compelled to serve their sentences under the control of a separate corrective system. But what happens with the defenceless child who is caned? Quite often the accuser, the judge and the person who metes out the punishment are one and the same person. Our society would not tolerate a similar system for those accused of criminal offences. By far the vast majority of teachers are hard-working, dedicated men and women who will not have a bar of the use of corporal punishment. The others who deliberately inflict pain on those whom they should be educating lose any right to regard themselves a professionals.

What would society say if people such as medical practitioners, nurses and psychologists used violence to counter their patients' behaviour problems? They would be disbarred, and rightly so. Yet we now face the bizarre situation where state-condoned violence is to be returned to a school system which had until yesterday projected a humane image. Many schools now have courses in peace studies and in many schools and in the wider community there is support for Australia to take a lead in the search for world peace. But is the next generation going to believe us when we hold that disputes should be resolved by other than violence and yet use violence against them at school? They are more likely to regard us as hypocrites.

My opposition to the use of corporal punishment is well documented. I therefore do not intend to make further remarks about this matter today. Before concluding, however, I would commend to honourable senators the editorial of today's Sydney Morning Herald. It has pained me to speak on this subject, but the almost unbelievable actions of what is supposed to be an educational administration in New South Wales should not go unnoticed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 9 March 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: In view of the reported possible co-operative action by Pacific nations against the drift gill-net fishing practice and New Zealand's encouragement for joint action to stop this unacceptable form of fishing, what are the Australian Government's attitude and intentions in this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There is little doubt that large numbers of gillnetting operations are occurring in the South Pacific and Tasman Sea with incidental catches of sea mammals and billfish in these operations.
Australia is very aware of the potential damage that can result from the use of pelagic gillnets, and has shown itself to be responsible in its attitude towards these operations in the past.

The introduction of legislation in 1986 prohibiting the use of pelagic gillnets over 2.5 kilometres in length in northern Australia has prevented any further pelagic gillnet operations by foreign and domestic fleets in that area.

Australia has joined other South Pacific nations in discussions on the effects of gillnetting operations and currently is considering the introduction of a ban on landing or transhipment of pelagic gillnet-caught fish, and preventing port access for any pelagic gillnet vessels. At present no such operations are occurring in Australian ports or the Australian Fishing Zone.
